and personal fulfillment.

00:01:27.433 --> 00:01:32.479
A recent study in the U.S.
showed that, of married senior managers,

00:01:32.503 --> 00:01:34.934
two-thirds of the married men had children

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:37.664
and only one-third
of the married women had children.

00:01:38.627 --> 00:01:40.637
A couple of years ago, I was in New York,

00:01:40.661 --> 00:01:42.117
and I was pitching a deal,

00:01:42.141 --> 00:01:45.492
and I was in one of those fancy
New York private equity offices

00:01:45.516 --> 00:01:46.689
you can picture.

00:01:46.713 --> 00:01:49.523
And I'm in the meeting --
it's about a three-hour meeting --

00:01:49.547 --> 00:01:52.706
and two hours in,
there needs to be that bio break,

00:01:52.730 --> 00:01:54.537
and everyone stands up,

00:01:54.561 --> 00:01:57.847
and the partner running the meeting
starts looking really embarrassed.

00:01:58.219 --> 00:02:02.492
And I realized he doesn't know
where the women's room is in his office.

00:02:02.516 --> 00:02:05.059
So I start looking
around for moving boxes,

00:02:05.083 --> 00:02:07.369
figuring they just moved in,
but I don't see any.

00:02:07.393 --> 00:02:10.337
And so I said, "Did you just
move into this office?"

00:02:10.718 --> 00:02:12.957
And he said, "No,
we've been here about a year."

00:02:13.587 --> 00:02:17.688
And I said, "Are you telling me
that I am the only woman

00:02:17.712 --> 00:02:20.494
to have pitched a deal
in this office in a year?"

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.544
And he looked at me, and he said,

00:02:22.568 --> 00:02:26.149
"Yeah. Or maybe you're the only one
who had to go to the bathroom."

00:02:26.173 --> 00:02:28.572
(Laughter)

00:02:28.596 --> 00:02:32.065
So the question is,
how are we going to fix this?

00:02:33.565 --> 00:02:36.817
How do we change these numbers at the top?

00:02:36.841 --> 00:02:38.934
How do we make this different?

00:02:39.577 --> 00:02:42.214
I want to start out by saying,
I talk about this --

00:02:42.238 --> 00:02:44.934
about keeping women in the workforce --

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.547
because I really think that's the answer.

00:02:47.571 --> 00:02:49.833
In the high-income part of our workforce,

00:02:49.857 --> 00:02:51.934
in the people who end up at the top --

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:56.934
Fortune 500 CEO jobs,
or the equivalent in other industries --

00:02:56.958 --> 00:03:00.605
the problem, I am convinced,
is that women are dropping out.

00:03:00.629 --> 00:03:02.934
Now people talk about this a lot,

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.972
and they talk about things
like flextime and mentoring

00:03:05.996 --> 00:03:08.481
and programs companies
should have to train women.

00:03:08.505 --> 00:03:10.410
I want to talk about none of that today,

00:03:10.434 --> 00:03:12.436
even though that's all really important.

00:03:12.460 --> 00:03:15.286
Today I want to focus
on what we can do as individuals.

00:03:15.653 --> 00:03:17.934
What are the messages
we need to tell ourselves?

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:21.122
What are the messages we tell
the women that work with and for us?

00:03:21.146 --> 00:03:23.231
What are the messages
we tell our daughters?

00:03:23.599 --> 00:03:25.998
Now, at the outset,
I want to be very clear

00:03:26.022 --> 00:03:28.104
that this speech comes with no judgments.

00:03:28.128 --> 00:03:29.708
I don't have the right answer.

00:03:29.732 --> 00:03:31.259
I don't even have it for myself.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.934
I left San Francisco,
where I live, on Monday,

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.724
and I was getting on the plane
for this conference.

00:03:37.748 --> 00:03:40.844
And my daughter, who's three,
when I dropped her off at preschool,

00:03:40.868 --> 00:03:44.535
did that whole hugging-the-leg, crying,
"Mommy, don't get on the plane" thing.

00:03:44.559 --> 00:03:47.381
This is hard. I feel guilty sometimes.

00:03:47.405 --> 00:03:48.934
I know no women,

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.768
whether they're at home
or whether they're in the workforce,

00:03:51.792 --> 00:03:53.331
who don't feel that sometimes.

00:03:53.355 --> 00:03:55.934
So I'm not saying
that staying in the workforce

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.783
is the right thing for everyone.

00:03:58.286 --> 00:04:00.934
My talk today is about
what the messages are

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.315
if you do want to stay in the workforce,

00:04:03.339 --> 00:04:04.934
and I think there are three.

00:04:05.473 --> 00:04:07.461
One, sit at the table.

00:04:07.862 --> 00:04:10.272
Two, make your partner a real partner.

00:04:11.164 --> 00:04:14.934
And three, don't leave before you leave.

00:04:15.754 --> 00:04:17.216
Number one: sit at the table.

00:04:17.812 --> 00:04:19.637
Just a couple weeks ago at Facebook,

00:04:19.661 --> 00:04:21.934
we hosted a very senior
government official,

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:25.179
and he came in to meet with senior execs

00:04:25.203 --> 00:04:26.804
from around Silicon Valley.

00:04:27.312 --> 00:04:29.494
And everyone kind of sat at the table.

00:04:29.518 --> 00:04:32.090
He had these two women
who were traveling with him

00:04:32.114 --> 00:04:33.934
pretty senior in his department,

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.244
and I kind of said to them,

00:04:35.268 --> 00:04:37.482
"Sit at the table.
Come on, sit at the table,"

00:04:37.506 --> 00:04:39.269
and they sat on the side of the room.

00:04:40.491 --> 00:04:42.443
When I was in college, my senior year,

00:04:42.467 --> 00:04:44.966
I took a course called
European Intellectual History.

00:04:44.990 --> 00:04:47.197
Don't you love that kind
of thing from college?

00:04:47.221 --> 00:04:48.934
I wish I could do that now.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.934
And I took it with my roommate, Carrie,

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.498
who was then a brilliant
literary student --

00:04:53.522 --> 00:04:55.832
and went on to be a brilliant
literary scholar --

00:04:55.856 --> 00:04:57.873
and my brother -- smart guy,

00:04:57.897 --> 00:04:59.512
but a water-polo-playing pre-med,

00:04:59.536 --> 00:05:00.934
who was a sophomore.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.934
The three of us take this class together.

00:05:03.516 --> 00:05:07.692
And then Carrie reads all the books
in the original Greek and Latin,

00:05:07.716 --> 00:05:09.408
goes to all the lectures.

00:05:09.432 --> 00:05:11.482
I read all the books in English

00:05:11.506 --> 00:05:13.163
and go to most of the lectures.

00:05:13.187 --> 00:05:14.934
My brother is kind of busy.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:18.670
He reads one book of 12
and goes to a couple of lectures,

00:05:18.694 --> 00:05:21.741
marches himself up to our room

00:05:21.765 --> 00:05:24.242
a couple days before the exam
to get himself tutored.

00:05:24.815 --> 00:05:27.496
The three of us go to the exam
together, and we sit down.

00:05:27.520 --> 00:05:29.679
And we sit there for three hours --

00:05:29.703 --> 00:05:32.084
and our little blue notebooks
-- yes, I'm that old.

00:05:32.108 --> 00:05:35.323
We walk out, we look at each other,
and we say, "How did you do?"

00:05:35.347 --> 00:05:38.824
And Carrie says, "Boy, I feel like
I didn't really draw out the main point

00:05:38.848 --> 00:05:40.423
on the Hegelian dialectic."

00:05:40.447 --> 00:05:43.372
And I say, "God, I really
wish I had really connected

00:05:43.396 --> 00:05:46.611
John Locke's theory of property
with the philosophers that follow."

00:05:46.635 --> 00:05:48.139
And my brother says,

00:05:48.163 --> 00:05:50.078
"I got the top grade in the class."

00:05:50.102 --> 00:05:52.047
(Laughter)

00:05:52.071 --> 00:05:54.167
"You got the top grade in the class?

00:05:54.191 --> 00:05:55.741
You don't know anything."

00:05:55.765 --> 00:05:57.165
(Laughter)

00:05:57.189 --> 00:06:01.737
The problem with these stories
is that they show what the data shows:

00:06:01.761 --> 00:06:05.251
women systematically
underestimate their own abilities.

00:06:05.275 --> 00:06:06.934
If you test men and women,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:10.552
and you ask them questions
on totally objective criteria like GPAs,

00:06:10.576 --> 00:06:12.440
men get it wrong slightly high,

00:06:12.464 --> 00:06:14.551
and women get it wrong slightly low.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.934
Women do not negotiate
for themselves in the workforce.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.934
A study in the last two years

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.575
of people entering
the workforce out of college

00:06:22.599 --> 00:06:26.934
showed that 57 percent
of boys entering, or men, I guess,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.359
are negotiating their first salary,

00:06:29.383 --> 00:06:31.461
and only seven percent of women.

00:06:32.095 --> 00:06:34.214
And most importantly,

00:06:34.238 --> 00:06:36.934
men attribute their success to themselves,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.612
and women attribute it
to other external factors.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.331
If you ask men why they did a good job,

00:06:42.355 --> 00:06:44.934
they'll say, "I'm awesome.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.934
Obviously. Why are you even asking?"

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.934
If you ask women why they did a good job,

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.934
what they'll say is someone helped them,

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.934
they got lucky, they worked really hard.

00:06:54.604 --> 00:06:55.934
Why does this matter?

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.934
Boy, it matters a lot.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.934
Because no one gets to the corner office

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.512
by sitting on the side, not at the table,

00:07:03.536 --> 00:07:05.539
and no one gets the promotion

00:07:05.563 --> 00:07:08.118
if they don't think
they deserve their success,

00:07:08.142 --> 00:07:10.934
or they don't even understand
their own success.

00:07:11.810 --> 00:07:13.574
I wish the answer were easy.

00:07:13.598 --> 00:07:16.210
I wish I could go tell
all the young women I work for,

00:07:16.234 --> 00:07:17.248
these fabulous women,

00:07:17.272 --> 00:07:19.522
"Believe in yourself
and negotiate for yourself.

00:07:19.546 --> 00:07:20.934
Own your own success."

00:07:21.324 --> 00:07:23.360
I wish I could tell that to my daughter.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.563
But it's not that simple.

00:07:25.870 --> 00:07:29.438
Because what the data shows,
above all else, is one thing,

00:07:29.462 --> 00:07:33.763
which is that success and likeability
are positively correlated for men

00:07:33.787 --> 00:07:35.773
and negatively correlated for women.

00:07:36.579 --> 00:07:39.813
And everyone's nodding,
because we all know this to be true.

00:07:40.170 --> 00:07:42.934
There's a really good study
that shows this really well.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.149
There's a famous Harvard
Business School study

00:07:45.173 --> 00:07:46.806
on a woman named Heidi Roizen.

00:07:46.830 --> 00:07:51.234
And she's an operator
in a company in Silicon Valley,

00:07:51.258 --> 00:07:52.934
and she uses her contacts

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.494
to become a very successful
venture capitalist.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.934
In 2002 -- not so long ago --

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.197
a professor who was then
at Columbia University

00:08:00.221 --> 00:08:02.604
took that case
and made it [Howard] Roizen.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:06.461
And he gave the case out, both of them,
to two groups of students.

00:08:06.485 --> 00:08:09.417
He changed exactly one word:

00:08:09.441 --> 00:08:10.934
"Heidi" to "Howard."

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.934
But that one word made
a really big difference.

00:08:14.505 --> 00:08:16.136
He then surveyed the students,

00:08:16.160 --> 00:08:18.826
and the good news was the students,
both men and women,

00:08:18.850 --> 00:08:21.244
thought Heidi and Howard
were equally competent,

00:08:21.268 --> 00:08:22.546
and that's good.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.641
The bad news was
that everyone liked Howard.

00:08:25.665 --> 00:08:27.665
He's a great guy.
You want to work for him.

00:08:27.689 --> 00:08:29.689
You want to spend the day
fishing with him.

00:08:29.713 --> 00:08:31.275
But Heidi? Not so sure.

00:08:31.299 --> 00:08:34.164
She's a little out for herself.
She's a little political.

00:08:34.188 --> 00:08:36.235
You're not sure
you'd want to work for her.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.583
This is the complication.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.268
We have to tell our daughters
and our colleagues,

00:08:41.292 --> 00:08:43.976
we have to tell ourselves
to believe we got the A,

00:08:44.000 --> 00:08:46.934
to reach for the promotion,
to sit at the table,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.737
and we have to do it in a world

00:08:48.761 --> 00:08:52.356
where, for them, there are sacrifices
they will make for that,

00:08:52.380 --> 00:08:54.667
even though for their brothers,
there are not.

00:08:55.775 --> 00:08:59.442
The saddest thing about all of this
is that it's really hard to remember this.

00:08:59.466 --> 00:09:02.514
And I'm about to tell a story
which is truly embarrassing for me,

00:09:02.538 --> 00:09:03.845
but I think important.

00:09:04.228 --> 00:09:07.425
I gave this talk at Facebook
not so long ago

00:09:07.449 --> 00:09:09.938
to about 100 employees,

00:09:09.962 --> 00:09:13.010
and a couple hours later,
there was a young woman who works there

00:09:13.034 --> 00:09:16.373
sitting outside my little desk,
and she wanted to talk to me.

00:09:16.397 --> 00:09:18.540
I said, okay, and she sat down,
and we talked.

00:09:18.564 --> 00:09:20.517
And she said, "I learned something today.

00:09:20.541 --> 00:09:22.596
I learned that I need to keep my hand up."

00:09:22.937 --> 00:09:23.969
"What do you mean?"

00:09:23.993 --> 00:09:25.787
She said, "You're giving this talk,

00:09:25.811 --> 00:09:28.108
and you said you would take
two more questions.

00:09:28.132 --> 00:09:30.212
I had my hand up with many other people,

00:09:30.236 --> 00:09:31.831
and you took two more questions.

00:09:31.855 --> 00:09:34.765
I put my hand down, and I noticed
all the women did the same,

00:09:34.789 --> 00:09:36.718
and then you took more questions,

00:09:36.742 --> 00:09:37.934
only from the men."

00:09:39.114 --> 00:09:40.405
And I thought to myself,

00:09:40.429 --> 00:09:43.234
"Wow, if it's me -- who cares
about this, obviously --

00:09:43.258 --> 00:09:45.192
giving this talk --

00:09:45.216 --> 00:09:50.934
and during this talk, I can't even notice
that the men's hands are still raised,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.934
and the women's hands are still raised,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.136
how good are we

00:09:54.160 --> 00:09:56.864
as managers of our companies
and our organizations

00:09:56.888 --> 00:09:59.413
at seeing that the men
are reaching for opportunities

00:09:59.437 --> 00:10:00.484
more than women?"

00:10:01.235 --> 00:10:03.625
We've got to get women
to sit at the table.

00:10:03.649 --> 00:10:04.650
(Cheers)

00:10:04.674 --> 00:10:07.882
(Applause)

00:10:07.906 --> 00:10:09.229
Message number two:

00:10:09.253 --> 00:10:11.140
Make your partner a real partner.

00:10:11.164 --> 00:10:14.355
I've become convinced that we've made
more progress in the workforce

00:10:14.379 --> 00:10:15.934
than we have in the home.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.169
The data shows this very clearly.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:23.137
If a woman and a man
work full-time and have a child,

00:10:23.161 --> 00:10:26.514
the woman does twice the amount
of housework the man does,

00:10:26.538 --> 00:10:30.934
and the woman does three times
the amount of childcare the man does.

00:10:31.405 --> 00:10:35.155
So she's got three jobs
or two jobs, and he's got one.

00:10:35.179 --> 00:10:38.206
Who do you think drops out
when someone needs to be home more?

00:10:38.772 --> 00:10:42.582
The causes of this are really complicated,
and I don't have time to go into them.

00:10:42.606 --> 00:10:46.542
And I don't think Sunday football-watching
and general laziness is the cause.

00:10:46.566 --> 00:10:48.780
I think the cause is more complicated.

00:10:48.804 --> 00:10:50.293
I think, as a society,

00:10:50.317 --> 00:10:52.534
we put more pressure
on our boys to succeed

00:10:52.558 --> 00:10:53.934
than we do on our girls.

00:10:54.412 --> 00:10:56.440
I know men that stay home

00:10:56.464 --> 00:10:59.531
and work in the home
to support wives with careers,

00:10:59.555 --> 00:11:00.582
and it's hard.

00:11:00.606 --> 00:11:03.934
When I go to the Mommy-and-Me stuff
and I see the father there,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:07.477
I notice that the other mommies
don't play with him.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.934
And that's a problem,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:13.144
because we have to make it
as important a job,

00:11:13.168 --> 00:11:16.547
because it's the hardest job
in the world to work inside the home,

00:11:16.571 --> 00:11:18.051
for people of both genders,

00:11:18.075 --> 00:11:21.569
if we're going to even things out and let
women stay in the workforce.

00:11:21.593 --> 00:11:22.934
(Applause)

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.197
Studies show that households
with equal earning

00:11:25.221 --> 00:11:27.163
and equal responsibility

00:11:27.187 --> 00:11:29.348
also have half the divorce rate.

00:11:29.372 --> 00:11:32.556
And if that wasn't good enough motivation
for everyone out there,

00:11:32.580 --> 00:11:34.393
they also have more --

00:11:34.417 --> 00:11:36.227
how shall I say this on this stage?

00:11:36.251 --> 00:11:38.934
They know each other more
in the biblical sense as well.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.451
(Cheers)

00:11:41.475 --> 00:11:43.410
Message number three:

00:11:43.434 --> 00:11:44.934
Don't leave before you leave.

00:11:45.497 --> 00:11:47.240
I think there's a really deep irony

00:11:47.264 --> 00:11:49.349
to the fact that actions
women are taking --

00:11:49.373 --> 00:11:50.934
and I see this all the time --

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:54.084
with the objective
of staying in the workforce

00:11:54.108 --> 00:11:56.673
actually lead to their eventually leaving.

00:11:56.697 --> 00:11:57.934
Here's what happens:

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.502
We're all busy. Everyone's busy.
A woman's busy.

00:12:00.526 --> 00:12:02.934
And she starts thinking
about having a child,

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.934
and from the moment she starts
thinking about having a child,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.482
she starts thinking
about making room for that child.

00:12:08.955 --> 00:12:11.766
"How am I going to fit this
into everything else I'm doing?"

00:12:12.140 --> 00:12:14.790
And literally from that moment,

00:12:14.814 --> 00:12:17.108
she doesn't raise her hand anymore,

00:12:17.132 --> 00:12:20.462
she doesn't look for a promotion,
she doesn't take on the new project,

00:12:20.486 --> 00:12:22.463
she doesn't say, "Me. I want to do that."

00:12:22.487 --> 00:12:23.761
She starts leaning back.

00:12:24.160 --> 00:12:25.557
The problem is that --

00:12:25.581 --> 00:12:29.145
let's say she got pregnant
that day, that day --

00:12:29.169 --> 00:12:31.934
nine months of pregnancy,
three months of maternity leave,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.108
six months to catch your breath --

00:12:34.132 --> 00:12:35.594
Fast-forward two years,

00:12:35.618 --> 00:12:37.578
more often -- and as I've seen it --

00:12:37.602 --> 00:12:40.116
women start thinking
about this way earlier --

00:12:40.140 --> 00:12:42.030
when they get engaged, or married,

00:12:42.054 --> 00:12:44.202
when they start thinking
about having a child,

00:12:44.226 --> 00:12:45.693
which can take a long time.

00:12:45.717 --> 00:12:47.725
One woman came to see me about this.

00:12:47.749 --> 00:12:49.478
She looked a little young.

00:12:49.502 --> 00:12:52.836
And I said, "So are you and your husband
thinking about having a baby?"

00:12:52.860 --> 00:12:54.822
And she said, "Oh no, I'm not married."

00:12:54.846 --> 00:12:56.421
She didn't even have a boyfriend.

00:12:56.445 --> 00:12:57.446
(Laughter)

00:12:57.470 --> 00:13:00.801
I said, "You're thinking about this
just way too early."

00:13:01.177 --> 00:13:03.795
But the point is that what happens

00:13:03.819 --> 00:13:06.467
once you start
kind of quietly leaning back?

00:13:07.501 --> 00:13:09.267
Everyone who's been through this --

00:13:09.291 --> 00:13:12.034
and I'm here to tell you,
once you have a child at home,

00:13:12.058 --> 00:13:14.644
your job better be really good to go back,

00:13:14.668 --> 00:13:16.811
because it's hard to leave
that kid at home.

00:13:16.835 --> 00:13:18.699
Your job needs to be challenging.

00:13:18.723 --> 00:13:20.389
It needs to be rewarding.

00:13:20.413 --> 00:13:22.934
You need to feel like you're
making a difference.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.934
And if two years ago
you didn't take a promotion

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.224
and some guy next to you did,

00:13:28.248 --> 00:13:31.934
if three years ago you stopped
looking for new opportunities,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.686
you're going to be bored

00:13:33.710 --> 00:13:36.403
because you should have kept
your foot on the gas pedal.

00:13:37.170 --> 00:13:39.565
Don't leave before you leave.

00:13:39.589 --> 00:13:40.934
Stay in.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.934
Keep your foot on the gas pedal,

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:47.589
until the very day you need to leave
to take a break for a child --

00:13:47.613 --> 00:13:49.399
and then make your decisions.

00:13:49.854 --> 00:13:52.332
Don't make decisions too far in advance,

00:13:52.356 --> 00:13:55.074
particularly ones you're not
even conscious you're making.

00:13:56.469 --> 00:13:58.210
My generation really, sadly,

00:13:58.234 --> 00:14:00.505
is not going to change
the numbers at the top.

00:14:00.529 --> 00:14:02.249
They're just not moving.

00:14:02.273 --> 00:14:05.475
We are not going to get
to where 50 percent of the population --

00:14:05.499 --> 00:14:08.166
in my generation, there will not
be 50 percent of [women]

00:14:08.190 --> 00:14:09.697
at the top of any industry.

00:14:10.828 --> 00:14:13.249
But I'm hopeful that future
generations can.

00:14:14.242 --> 00:14:18.931
I think a world where half
of our countries and our companies

00:14:18.955 --> 00:14:21.368
were run by women,
would be a better world.

00:14:21.392 --> 00:14:24.773
It's not just because people would know
where the women's bathrooms are,

00:14:24.797 --> 00:14:27.450
even though that would be very helpful.

00:14:27.474 --> 00:14:29.221
I think it would be a better world.

00:14:30.201 --> 00:14:31.476
I have two children.

00:14:31.500 --> 00:14:34.072
I have a five-year-old son
and a two-year-old daughter.

00:14:34.518 --> 00:14:36.195
I want my son to have a choice

00:14:36.219 --> 00:14:39.291
to contribute fully
in the workforce or at home,

00:14:39.315 --> 00:14:43.211
and I want my daughter
to have the choice to not just succeed,

00:14:43.235 --> 00:14:45.934
but to be liked for her accomplishments.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.068
Thank you.

00:14:47.092 --> 00:14:48.958
(Applause)

title: 3 stories of local eco-entrepreneurship
transcript: So today, I'm going to tell you about some people who didn't move out of their neighborhoods. The first one is happening right here in Chicago. Brenda Palms-Farber was hired to help ex-convicts reenter society and keep them from going back into prison. Currently, taxpayers spend about 60,000 dollars per year sending a person to jail. We know that two-thirds of them are going to go back. I find it interesting that, for every one dollar we spend, however, on early childhood education, like Head Start, we save 17 dollars on stuff like incarceration in the future. Or — think about it — that 60,000 dollars is more than what it costs to send one person to Harvard as well.But Brenda, not being phased by stuff like that, took a look at her challenge and came up with a not-so-obvious solution: create a business that produces skin care products from honey. Okay, it might be obvious to some of you; it wasn't to me. It's the basis of growing a form of social innovation that has real potential. She hired seemingly unemployable men and women to care for the bees, harvest the honey and make value-added products that they marketed themselves, and that were later sold at Whole Foods. She combined employment experience and training with life skills they needed, like anger-management and teamwork, and also how to talk to future employers about how their experiences actually demonstrated the lessons that they had learned and their eagerness to learn more. Less than four percent of the folks that went through her program actually go back to jail. So these young men and women learned job-readiness and life skills through bee keeping and became productive citizens in the process. Talk about a sweet beginning.Now, I'm going to take you to Los Angeles, and lots of people know that L.A. has its issues. But I'm going to talk about L.A.'s water issues right now. They have not enough water on most days and too much to handle when it rains. Currently, 20 percent of California's energy consumption is used to pump water into mostly Southern California. Their spending loads, loads, to channel that rainwater out into the ocean when it rains and floods as well. Now Andy Lipkis is working to help L.A. cut infrastructure costs associated with water management and urban heat island — linking trees, people and technology to create a more livable city. All that green stuff actually naturally absorbs storm water, also helps cool our cities. Because, come to think about it, do you really want air-conditioning, or is it a cooler room that you want? How you get it shouldn't make that much of a difference.So a few years ago, L.A. County decided that they needed to spend 2.5 billion dollars to repair the city schools. And Andy and his team discovered that they were going to spend 200 million of those dollars on asphalt to surround the schools themselves. And by presenting a really strong economic case, they convinced the L.A. government that replacing that asphalt with trees and other greenery, that the schools themselves would save the system more on energy than they spend on horticultural infrastructure. So ultimately, 20 million square feet of asphalt was replaced or avoided, and electrical consumption for air-conditioning went down, while employment for people to maintain those grounds went up, resulting in a net-savings to the system, but also healthier students and schools system employees as well.Now Judy Bonds is a coal miner's daughter. Her family has eight generations in a town called Whitesville, West Virginia. And if anyone should be clinging to the former glory of the coal mining history, and of the town, it should be Judy. But the way coal is mined right now is different from the deep mines that her father and her father's father would go down into and that employed essentially thousands and thousands of people. Now, two dozen men can tear down a mountain in several months, and only for about a few years' worth of coal. That kind of technology is called "mountaintop removal." It can make a mountain go from this to this in a few short months. Just imagine that the air surrounding these places — it's filled with the residue of explosives and coal. When we visited, it gave some of the people we were with this strange little cough after being only there for just a few hours or so — not just miners, but everybody.And Judy saw her landscape being destroyed and her water poisoned. And the coal companies just move on after the mountain was emptied, leaving even more unemployment in their wake. But she also saw the difference in potential wind energy on an intact mountain, and one that was reduced in elevation by over 2,000 feet. Three years of dirty energy with not many jobs, or centuries of clean energy with the potential for developing expertise and improvements in efficiency based on technical skills, and developing local knowledge about how to get the most out of that region's wind. She calculated the up-front cost and the payback over time, and it's a net-plus on so many levels for the local, national and global economy. It's a longer payback than mountaintop removal, but the wind energy actually pays back forever. Now mountaintop removal pays very little money to the locals, and it gives them a lot of misery. The water is turned into goo. Most people are still unemployed, leading to most of the same kinds of social problems that unemployed people in inner cities also experience — drug and alcohol abuse, domestic abuse, teen pregnancy and poor heath, as well.Now Judy and I — I have to say — totally related to each other. Not quite an obvious alliance. I mean, literally, her hometown is called Whitesville, West Virginia. I mean, they are not — they ain't competing for the birthplace of hip hop title or anything like that. But the back of my T-shirt, the one that she gave me, says, "Save the endangered hillbillies." So homegirls and hillbillies we got it together and totally understand that this is what it's all about. But just a few months ago, Judy was diagnosed with stage-three lung cancer. Yeah. And it has since moved to her bones and her brain. And I just find it so bizarre that she's suffering from the same thing that she tried so hard to protect people from. But her dream of Coal River Mountain Wind is her legacy. And she might not get to see that mountaintop. But rather than writing yet some kind of manifesto or something, she's leaving behind a business plan to make it happen. That's what my homegirl is doing. So I'm so proud of that.(Applause)But these three people don't know each other, but they do have an awful lot in common. They're all problem solvers, and they're just some of the many examples that I really am privileged to see, meet and learn from in the examples of the work that I do now. I was really lucky to have them all featured on my Corporation for Public Radio radio show called ThePromisedLand.org. Now they're all very practical visionaries. They take a look at the demands that are out there — beauty products, healthy schools, electricity — and how the money's flowing to meet those demands. And when the cheapest solutions involve reducing the number of jobs, you're left with unemployed people, and those people aren't cheap. In fact, they make up some of what I call the most expensive citizens, and they include generationally impoverished, traumatized vets returning from the Middle East, people coming out of jail. And for the veterans in particular, the V.A. said there's a six-fold increase in mental health pharmaceuticals by vets since 2003. I think that number's probably going to go up. They're not the largest number of people, but they are some of the most expensive — and in terms of the likelihood for domestic abuse, drug and alcohol abuse, poor performance by their kids in schools and also poor health as a result of stress. So these three guys all understand how to productively channel dollars through our local economies to meet existing market demands, reduce the social problems that we have now and prevent new problems in the future.And there are plenty of other examples like that. One problem: waste handling and unemployment. Even when we think or talk about recycling, lots of recyclable stuff ends up getting incinerated or in landfills and leaving many municipalities, diversion rates — they leave much to be recycled. And where is this waste handled? Usually in poor communities. And we know that eco-industrial business, these kinds of business models — there's a model in Europe called the eco-industrial park, where either the waste of one company is the raw material for another, or you use recycled materials to make goods that you can actually use and sell. We can create these local markets and incentives for recycled materials to be used as raw materials for manufacturing. And in my hometown, we actually tried to do one of these in the Bronx, but our mayor decided what he wanted to see was a jail on that same spot. Fortunately — because we wanted to create hundreds of jobs — but after many years, the city wanted to build a jail. They've since abandoned that project, thank goodness.Another problem: unhealthy food systems and unemployment. Working-class and poor urban Americans are not benefiting economically from our current food system. It relies too much on transportation, chemical fertilization, big use of water and also refrigeration. Mega agricultural operations often are responsible for poisoning our waterways and our land, and it produces this incredibly unhealthy product that costs us billions in healthcare and lost productivity. And so we know "urban ag" is a big buzz topic this time of the year, but it's mostly gardening, which has some value in community building — lots of it — but it's not in terms of creating jobs or for food production. The numbers just aren't there. Part of my work now is really laying the groundwork to integrate urban ag and rural food systems to hasten the demise of the 3,000-mile salad by creating a national brand of urban-grown produce in every city, that uses regional growing power and augments it with indoor growing facilities, owned and operated by small growers, where now there are only consumers. This can support seasonal farmers around metro areas who are losing out because they really can't meet the year-round demand for produce. It's not a competition with rural farm; it's actually reinforcements. It allies in a really positive and economically viable food system.The goal is to meet the cities' institutional demands for hospitals, senior centers, schools, daycare centers, and produce a network of regional jobs, as well. This is smart infrastructure. And how we manage our built environment affects the health and well-being of people every single day. Our municipalities, rural and urban, play the operational course of infrastructure — things like waste disposal, energy demand, as well as social costs of unemployment, drop-out rates, incarceration rates and the impacts of various public health costs. Smart infrastructure can provide cost-saving ways for municipalities to handle both infrastructure and social needs. And we want to shift the systems that open the doors for people who were formerly tax burdens to become part of the tax base. And imagine a national business model that creates local jobs and smart infrastructure to improve local economic stability. So I'm hoping you can see a little theme here.These examples indicate a trend. I haven't created it, and it's not happening by accident. I'm noticing that it's happening all over the country, and the good news is that it's growing. And we all need to be invested in it. It is an essential pillar to this country's recovery. And I call it "hometown security." The recession has us reeling and fearful, and there's something in the air these days that is also very empowering. It's a realization that we are the key to our own recovery. Now is the time for us to act in our own communities where we think local and we act local. And when we do that, our neighbors — be they next-door, or in the next state, or in the next country — will be just fine. The sum of the local is the global. Hometown security means rebuilding our natural defenses, putting people to work, restoring our natural systems. Hometown security means creating wealth here at home, instead of destroying it overseas. Tackling social and environmental problems at the same time with the same solution yields great cost savings, wealth generation and national security. Many great and inspiring solutions have been generated across America. The challenge for us now is to identify and support countless more.Now, hometown security is about taking care of your own, but it's not like the old saying, "charity begins at home." I recently read a book called "Love Leadership" by John Hope Bryant. And it's about leading in a world that really does seem to be operating on the basis of fear. And reading that book made me reexamine that theory because I need to explain what I mean by that. See, my dad was a great, great man in many ways. He grew up in the segregated South, escaped lynching and all that during some really hard times, and he provided a really stable home for me and my siblings and a whole bunch of other people that fell on hard times. But, like all of us, he had some problems. (Laughter) And his was gambling, compulsively. To him that phrase, "Charity begins at home," meant that my payday — or someone else's — would just happen to coincide with his lucky day. So you need to help him out. And sometimes I would loan him money from my after-school or summer jobs, and he always had the great intention of paying me back with interest, of course, after he hit it big. And he did sometimes, believe it or not, at a racetrack in Los Angeles — one reason to love L.A. — back in the 1940s. He made 15,000 dollars cash and bought the house that I grew up in. So I'm not that unhappy about that. But listen, I did feel obligated to him, and I grew up — then I grew up. And I'm a grown woman now, and I have learned a few things along the way.To me, charity often is just about giving, because you're supposed to, or because it's what you've always done, or it's about giving until it hurts. I'm about providing the means to build something that will grow and intensify its original investment and not just require greater giving next year — I'm not trying to feed the habit. I spent some years watching how good intentions for community empowerment, that were supposed to be there to support the community and empower it, actually left people in the same, if not worse, position that they were in before. And over the past 20 years, we've spent record amounts of philanthropic dollars on social problems, yet educational outcomes, malnutrition, incarceration, obesity, diabetes, income disparity, they've all gone up with some exceptions — in particular, infant mortality among people in poverty — but it's a great world that we're bringing them into as well.And I know a little bit about these issues, because, for many years, I spent a long time in the non-profit industrial complex, and I'm a recovering executive director, two years clean. (Laughter) But during that time, I realized that it was about projects and developing them on the local level that really was going to do the right thing for our communities. But I really did struggle for financial support. The greater our success, the less money came in from foundations. And I tell you, being on the TED stage and winning a MacArthur in the same exact year gave everyone the impression that I had arrived. And by the time I'd moved on, I was actually covering a third of my agency's budget deficit with speaking fees. And I think because early on, frankly, my programs were just a little bit ahead of their time. But since then, the park that was just a dump and was featured at a TED2006 Talk became this little thing. But I did in fact get married in it. Over here. There goes my dog who led me to the park in my wedding. The South Bronx Greenway was also just a drawing on the stage back in 2006. Since then, we got about 50 million dollars in stimulus package money to come and get here. And we love this, because I love construction now, because we're watching these things actually happen.So I want everyone to understand the critical importance of shifting charity into enterprise. I started my firm to help communities across the country realize their own potential to improve everything about the quality of life for their people. Hometown security is next on my to-do list. What we need are people who see the value in investing in these types of local enterprises, who will partner with folks like me to identify the growth trends and climate adaptation as well as understand the growing social costs of business as usual. We need to work together to embrace and repair our land, repair our power systems and repair ourselves. It's time to stop building the shopping malls, the prisons, the stadiums and other tributes to all of our collective failures. It is time that we start building living monuments to hope and possibility.Thank you very much.(Applause)

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
When we visited, it gave some of the people we were with

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
this strange little cough

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
after being only there for just a few hours or so --

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
not just miners, but everybody.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
And Judy saw her landscape being destroyed

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
and her water poisoned.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
And the coal companies just move on

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
after the mountain was emptied,

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
leaving even more unemployment in their wake.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
But she also saw the difference in potential wind energy

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
on an intact mountain,

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
and one that was reduced in elevation

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
by over 2,000 feet.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
Three years of dirty energy with not many jobs,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
or centuries of clean energy

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
with the potential for developing expertise and improvements in efficiency

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
based on technical skills,

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
and developing local knowledge

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
about how to get the most out of that region's wind.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
She calculated the up-front cost

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
and the payback over time,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.958
and it's a net-plus on so many levels

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
for the local, national and global economy.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
It's a longer payback than mountaintop removal,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
but the wind energy actually pays back forever.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
Now mountaintop removal pays very little money to the locals,

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
and it gives them a lot of misery.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
The water is turned into goo.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
Most people are still unemployed,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
leading to most of the same kinds of social problems

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
that unemployed people in inner cities also experience --

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
drug and alcohol abuse,

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
domestic abuse, teen pregnancy and poor heath, as well.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
Now Judy and I -- I have to say --

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
totally related to each other.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
Not quite an obvious alliance.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
I mean, literally, her hometown is called Whitesville, West Virginia.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
I mean, they are not --

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
they ain't competing for the birthplace of hip hop title

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
or anything like that.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
But the back of my T-shirt, the one that she gave me,

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
says, "Save the endangered hillbillies."

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
So homegirls and hillbillies we got it together

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
and totally understand that this is what it's all about.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
But just a few months ago,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
Judy was diagnosed

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
with stage-three lung cancer.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
Yeah.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
And it has since moved to her bones and her brain.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
And I just find it so bizarre

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
that she's suffering from the same thing

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
that she tried so hard to protect people from.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
But her dream

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
of Coal River Mountain Wind

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
is her legacy.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
And she might not

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
get to see that mountaintop.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
But rather than writing

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
yet some kind of manifesto or something,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
she's leaving behind

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
a business plan to make it happen.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
That's what my homegirl is doing.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
So I'm so proud of that.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:06.958
(Applause)

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
But these three people

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
don't know each other,

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
but they do have an awful lot in common.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
They're all problem solvers,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
and they're just some of the many examples

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
that I really am privileged to see, meet and learn from

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
in the examples of the work that I do now.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
I was really lucky to have them all featured

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
on my Corporation for Public Radio radio show

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
called ThePromisedLand.org.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
Now they're all very practical visionaries.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
They take a look at the demands that are out there --

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
beauty products, healthy schools, electricity --

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
and how the money's flowing to meet those demands.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
And when the cheapest solutions

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
involve reducing the number of jobs,

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
you're left with unemployed people,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
and those people aren't cheap.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
In fact, they make up some of what I call the most expensive citizens,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
and they include generationally impoverished,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
traumatized vets returning from the Middle East,

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
people coming out of jail.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
And for the veterans in particular,

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.958
the V.A. said there's a six-fold increase

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
in mental health pharmaceuticals by vets since 2003.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
I think that number's probably going to go up.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
They're not the largest number of people,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
but they are some of the most expensive --

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
and in terms of the likelihood for domestic abuse, drug and alcohol abuse,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
poor performance by their kids in schools

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
and also poor health as a result of stress.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
So these three guys all understand

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
how to productively channel dollars

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
through our local economies

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
to meet existing market demands,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
reduce the social problems that we have now

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
and prevent new problems in the future.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
And there are plenty of other examples like that.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
One problem: waste handling and unemployment.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
Even when we think or talk about recycling,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
lots of recyclable stuff ends up getting incinerated or in landfills

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
and leaving many municipalities, diversion rates --

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
they leave much to be recycled.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
And where is this waste handled? Usually in poor communities.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
And we know that eco-industrial business, these kinds of business models --

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
there's a model in Europe called the eco-industrial park,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
where either the waste of one company is the raw material for another,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
or you use recycled materials

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
to make goods that you can actually use and sell.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
We can create these local markets and incentives

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
for recycled materials

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
to be used as raw materials for manufacturing.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
And in my hometown, we actually tried to do one of these in the Bronx,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
but our mayor decided what he wanted to see

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
was a jail on that same spot.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
Fortunately -- because we wanted to create hundreds of jobs --

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
but after many years,

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
the city wanted to build a jail.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
They've since abandoned that project, thank goodness.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
Another problem: unhealthy food systems and unemployment.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
Working-class and poor urban Americans

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
are not benefiting economically

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
from our current food system.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
It relies too much on transportation,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
chemical fertilization, big use of water

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
and also refrigeration.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
Mega agricultural operations

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
often are responsible for poisoning our waterways and our land,

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
and it produces this incredibly unhealthy product

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
that costs us billions in healthcare

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
and lost productivity.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
And so we know "urban ag"

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
is a big buzz topic this time of the year,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
but it's mostly gardening,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
which has some value in community building -- lots of it --

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
but it's not in terms of creating jobs

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
or for food production.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
The numbers just aren't there.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
Part of my work now is really laying the groundwork

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
to integrate urban ag and rural food systems

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
to hasten the demise of the 3,000-mile salad

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
by creating a national brand of urban-grown produce

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
in every city,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
that uses regional growing power

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
and augments it with indoor growing facilities,

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
owned and operated by small growers,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
where now there are only consumers.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
This can support seasonal farmers around metro areas

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
who are losing out because they really can't meet

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
the year-round demand for produce.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
It's not a competition with rural farm;

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
it's actually reinforcements.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
It allies in a really positive

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
and economically viable food system.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
The goal is to meet the cities' institutional demands

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
for hospitals,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
senior centers, schools, daycare centers,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and produce a network of regional jobs, as well.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
This is smart infrastructure.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
And how we manage our built environment

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
affects the health and well-being of people every single day.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
Our municipalities, rural and urban,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
play the operational course of infrastructure --

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
things like waste disposal, energy demand,

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
as well as social costs of unemployment, drop-out rates, incarceration rates

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
and the impacts of various public health costs.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
Smart infrastructure can provide cost-saving ways

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
for municipalities to handle

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
both infrastructure and social needs.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
And we want to shift the systems

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
that open the doors for people who were formerly tax burdens

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
to become part of the tax base.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
And imagine a national business model

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
that creates local jobs and smart infrastructure

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
to improve local economic stability.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
So I'm hoping you can see a little theme here.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
These examples indicate a trend.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:43.958
I haven't created it, and it's not happening by accident.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
I'm noticing that it's happening all over the country,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
and the good news is that it's growing.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
And we all need to be invested in it.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
It is an essential pillar to this country's recovery.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
And I call it "hometown security."

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
The recession has us reeling and fearful,

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
and there's something in the air these days

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
that is also very empowering.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
It's a realization

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
that we are the key

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
to our own recovery.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
Now is the time for us to act in our own communities

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
where we think local and we act local.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
And when we do that, our neighbors --

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
be they next-door, or in the next state,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
or in the next country --

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
will be just fine.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
The sum of the local is the global.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
Hometown security means rebuilding our natural defenses,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
putting people to work,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
restoring our natural systems.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
Hometown security means creating wealth here at home,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
instead of destroying it overseas.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
Tackling social and environmental problems

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.958
at the same time with the same solution

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
yields great cost savings,

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
wealth generation and national security.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Many great and inspiring solutions

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
have been generated across America.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
The challenge for us now

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
is to identify and support countless more.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
Now, hometown security is about taking care of your own,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
but it's not like the old saying,

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
"charity begins at home."

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
I recently read a book called "Love Leadership" by John Hope Bryant.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
And it's about leading in a world

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
that really does seem to be operating on the basis of fear.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
And reading that book made me reexamine that theory

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
because I need to explain what I mean by that.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
See, my dad

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
was a great, great man in many ways.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
He grew up in the segregated South,

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
escaped lynching and all that

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
during some really hard times,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
and he provided a really stable home for me and my siblings

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
and a whole bunch of other people that fell on hard times.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
But, like all of us, he had some problems.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
(Laughter)

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
And his was gambling,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
compulsively.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
To him that phrase, "Charity begins at home,"

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
meant that my payday -- or someone else's --

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
would just happen to coincide with his lucky day.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
So you need to help him out.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And sometimes I would loan him money

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
from my after-school or summer jobs,

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
and he always had the great intention

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
of paying me back with interest,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
of course, after he hit it big.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
And he did sometimes, believe it or not,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
at a racetrack in Los Angeles --

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
one reason to love L.A. -- back in the 1940s.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
He made 15,000 dollars cash

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
and bought the house that I grew up in.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
So I'm not that unhappy about that.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:22.958
But listen, I did feel obligated to him,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
and I grew up -- then I grew up.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And I'm a grown woman now,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
and I have learned a few things along the way.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
To me, charity

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
often is just about giving,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
because you're supposed to,

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
or because it's what you've always done,

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
or it's about giving until it hurts.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
I'm about providing the means

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
to build something that will grow

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
and intensify its original investment

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
and not just require greater giving next year --

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
I'm not trying to feed the habit.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
I spent some years

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
watching how good intentions for community empowerment,

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
that were supposed to be there

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
to support the community and empower it,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
actually left people

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
in the same, if not worse, position that they were in before.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
And over the past 20 years,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
we've spent record amounts of philanthropic dollars

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
on social problems,

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
yet educational outcomes,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
malnutrition, incarceration,

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
obesity, diabetes, income disparity,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
they've all gone up with some exceptions --

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
in particular, infant mortality

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
among people in poverty --

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
but it's a great world that we're bringing them into as well.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
And I know a little bit about these issues,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
because, for many years, I spent a long time

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
in the non-profit industrial complex,

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
and I'm a recovering executive director,

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
two years clean.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
(Laughter)

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:46.958
But during that time, I realized that it was about projects

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
and developing them on the local level

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
that really was going to do the right thing for our communities.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
But I really did struggle for financial support.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
The greater our success,

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
the less money came in from foundations.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
And I tell you, being on the TED stage

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
and winning a MacArthur in the same exact year

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
gave everyone the impression that I had arrived.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
And by the time I'd moved on,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
I was actually covering a third

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
of my agency's budget deficit with speaking fees.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
And I think because early on, frankly,

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
my programs were just a little bit ahead of their time.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
But since then,

title: The power of vulnerability
transcript: So, I'll start with this: a couple years ago, an event planner called me because I was going to do a speaking event. And she called, and she said, "I'm really struggling with how to write about you on the little flyer." And I thought, "Well, what's the struggle?" And she said, "Well, I saw you speak, and I'm going to call you a researcher, I think, but I'm afraid if I call you a researcher, no one will come, because they'll think you're boring and irrelevant."(Laughter)And I was like, "Okay." And she said, "But the thing I liked about your talk is you're a storyteller. So I think what I'll do is just call you a storyteller." And of course, the academic, insecure part of me was like, "You're going to call me a what?" And she said, "I'm going to call you a storyteller." And I was like, "Why not 'magic pixie'?"(Laughter)I was like, "Let me think about this for a second." I tried to call deep on my courage. And I thought, you know, I am a storyteller. I'm a qualitative researcher. I collect stories; that's what I do. And maybe stories are just data with a soul. And maybe I'm just a storyteller. And so I said, "You know what? Why don't you just say I'm a researcher-storyteller." And she went, "Ha ha. There's no such thing."(Laughter)So I'm a researcher-storyteller, and I'm going to talk to you today — we're talking about expanding perception — and so I want to talk to you and tell some stories about a piece of my research that fundamentally expanded my perception and really actually changed the way that I live and love and work and parent.And this is where my story starts. When I was a young researcher, doctoral student, my first year, I had a research professor who said to us, "Here's the thing, if you cannot measure it, it does not exist." And I thought he was just sweet-talking me. I was like, "Really?" and he was like, "Absolutely." And so you have to understand that I have a bachelor's and a master's in social work, and I was getting my Ph.D. in social work, so my entire academic career was surrounded by people who kind of believed in the "life's messy, love it." And I'm more of the, "life's messy, clean it up, organize it and put it into a bento box."(Laughter)And so to think that I had found my way, to found a career that takes me — really, one of the big sayings in social work is, "Lean into the discomfort of the work." And I'm like, knock discomfort upside the head and move it over and get all A's. That was my mantra. So I was very excited about this. And so I thought, you know what, this is the career for me, because I am interested in some messy topics. But I want to be able to make them not messy. I want to understand them. I want to hack into these things that I know are important and lay the code out for everyone to see.So where I started was with connection. Because, by the time you're a social worker for 10 years, what you realize is that connection is why we're here. It's what gives purpose and meaning to our lives. This is what it's all about. It doesn't matter whether you talk to people who work in social justice, mental health and abuse and neglect, what we know is that connection, the ability to feel connected, is — neurobiologically that's how we're wired — it's why we're here.So I thought, you know what, I'm going to start with connection. Well, you know that situation where you get an evaluation from your boss, and she tells you 37 things that you do really awesome, and one "opportunity for growth?"(Laughter)And all you can think about is that opportunity for growth, right? Well, apparently this is the way my work went as well, because, when you ask people about love, they tell you about heartbreak. When you ask people about belonging, they'll tell you their most excruciating experiences of being excluded. And when you ask people about connection, the stories they told me were about disconnection.So very quickly — really about six weeks into this research — I ran into this unnamed thing that absolutely unraveled connection in a way that I didn't understand or had never seen. And so I pulled back out of the research and thought, I need to figure out what this is. And it turned out to be shame. And shame is really easily understood as the fear of disconnection: Is there something about me that, if other people know it or see it, that I won't be worthy of connection?The things I can tell you about it: It's universal; we all have it. The only people who don't experience shame have no capacity for human empathy or connection. No one wants to talk about it, and the less you talk about it, the more you have it. What underpinned this shame, this "I'm not good enough," — which, we all know that feeling: "I'm not blank enough. I'm not thin enough, rich enough, beautiful enough, smart enough, promoted enough." The thing that underpinned this was excruciating vulnerability. This idea of, in order for connection to happen, we have to allow ourselves to be seen, really seen.And you know how I feel about vulnerability. I hate vulnerability. And so I thought, this is my chance to beat it back with my measuring stick. I'm going in, I'm going to figure this stuff out, I'm going to spend a year, I'm going to totally deconstruct shame, I'm going to understand how vulnerability works, and I'm going to outsmart it. So I was ready, and I was really excited. As you know, it's not going to turn out well.(Laughter)You know this. So, I could tell you a lot about shame, but I'd have to borrow everyone else's time. But here's what I can tell you that it boils down to — and this may be one of the most important things that I've ever learned in the decade of doing this research.My one year turned into six years: Thousands of stories, hundreds of long interviews, focus groups. At one point, people were sending me journal pages and sending me their stories — thousands of pieces of data in six years. And I kind of got a handle on it. I kind of understood, this is what shame is, this is how it works. I wrote a book, I published a theory, but something was not okay — and what it was is that, if I roughly took the people I interviewed and divided them into people who really have a sense of worthiness — that's what this comes down to, a sense of worthiness — they have a strong sense of love and belonging — and folks who struggle for it, and folks who are always wondering if they're good enough.There was only one variable that separated the people who have a strong sense of love and belonging and the people who really struggle for it. And that was, the people who have a strong sense of love and belonging believe they're worthy of love and belonging. That's it. They believe they're worthy. And to me, the hard part of the one thing that keeps us out of connection is our fear that we're not worthy of connection, was something that, personally and professionally, I felt like I needed to understand better. So what I did is I took all of the interviews where I saw worthiness, where I saw people living that way, and just looked at those.What do these people have in common? I have a slight office supply addiction, but that's another talk. So I had a manila folder, and I had a Sharpie, and I was like, what am I going to call this research? And the first words that came to my mind were "whole-hearted." These are whole-hearted people, living from this deep sense of worthiness. So I wrote at the top of the manila folder, and I started looking at the data. In fact, I did it first in a four-day, very intensive data analysis, where I went back, pulled the interviews, the stories, pulled the incidents. What's the theme? What's the pattern? My husband left town with the kids because I always go into this Jackson Pollock crazy thing, where I'm just writing and in my researcher mode.And so here's what I found. What they had in common was a sense of courage. And I want to separate courage and bravery for you for a minute. Courage, the original definition of courage, when it first came into the English language — it's from the Latin word "cor," meaning "heart" — and the original definition was to tell the story of who you are with your whole heart. And so these folks had, very simply, the courage to be imperfect. They had the compassion to be kind to themselves first and then to others, because, as it turns out, we can't practice compassion with other people if we can't treat ourselves kindly. And the last was they had connection, and — this was the hard part — as a result of authenticity, they were willing to let go of who they thought they should be in order to be who they were, which you have to absolutely do that for connection.The other thing that they had in common was this: They fully embraced vulnerability. They believed that what made them vulnerable made them beautiful. They didn't talk about vulnerability being comfortable, nor did they really talk about it being excruciating — as I had heard it earlier in the shame interviewing. They just talked about it being necessary. They talked about the willingness to say, "I love you" first ... the willingness to do something where there are no guarantees ... the willingness to breathe through waiting for the doctor to call after your mammogram. They're willing to invest in a relationship that may or may not work out. They thought this was fundamental.I personally thought it was betrayal. I could not believe I had pledged allegiance to research, where our job — you know, the definition of research is to control and predict, to study phenomena for the explicit reason to control and predict. And now my mission to control and predict had turned up the answer that the way to live is with vulnerability and to stop controlling and predicting. This led to a little breakdown —(Laughter)— which actually looked more like this.(Laughter)And it did.I call it a breakdown; my therapist calls it a spiritual awakening.(Laughter)A spiritual awakening sounds better than breakdown, but I assure you, it was a breakdown. And I had to put my data away and go find a therapist. Let me tell you something: you know who you are when you call your friends and say, "I think I need to see somebody. Do you have any recommendations?" Because about five of my friends were like, "Wooo, I wouldn't want to be your therapist."(Laughter)I was like, "What does that mean?" And they're like, "I'm just saying, you know. Don't bring your measuring stick."(Laughter)I was like, "Okay." So I found a therapist. My first meeting with her, Diana — I brought in my list of the way the whole-hearted live, and I sat down. And she said, "How are you?" And I said, "I'm great. I'm okay." She said, "What's going on?" And this is a therapist who sees therapists, because we have to go to those, because their B.S. meters are good.(Laughter)And so I said, "Here's the thing, I'm struggling." And she said, "What's the struggle?" And I said, "Well, I have a vulnerability issue. And I know that vulnerability is the core of shame and fear and our struggle for worthiness, but it appears that it's also the birthplace of joy, of creativity, of belonging, of love. And I think I have a problem, and I need some help." And I said, "But here's the thing: no family stuff, no childhood shit."(Laughter)"I just need some strategies."(Laughter)(Applause)Thank you. So she goes like this.(Laughter)And then I said, "It's bad, right?" And she said, "It's neither good nor bad."(Laughter)"It just is what it is." And I said, "Oh my God, this is going to suck."(Laughter)And it did, and it didn't. And it took about a year. And you know how there are people that, when they realize that vulnerability and tenderness are important, that they surrender and walk into it. A: that's not me, and B: I don't even hang out with people like that.(Laughter)For me, it was a yearlong street fight. It was a slugfest. Vulnerability pushed, I pushed back. I lost the fight, but probably won my life back.And so then I went back into the research and spent the next couple of years really trying to understand what they, the whole-hearted, what choices they were making, and what we are doing with vulnerability. Why do we struggle with it so much? Am I alone in struggling with vulnerability? No.So this is what I learned. We numb vulnerability — when we're waiting for the call. It was funny, I sent something out on Twitter and on Facebook that says, "How would you define vulnerability? What makes you feel vulnerable?" And within an hour and a half, I had 150 responses. Because I wanted to know what's out there. Having to ask my husband for help because I'm sick, and we're newly married; initiating sex with my husband; initiating sex with my wife; being turned down; asking someone out; waiting for the doctor to call back; getting laid off; laying off people. This is the world we live in. We live in a vulnerable world. And one of the ways we deal with it is we numb vulnerability.And I think there's evidence — and it's not the only reason this evidence exists, but I think it's a huge cause — We are the most in-debt ... obese ... addicted and medicated adult cohort in U.S. history. The problem is — and I learned this from the research — that you cannot selectively numb emotion. You can't say, here's the bad stuff. Here's vulnerability, here's grief, here's shame, here's fear, here's disappointment. I don't want to feel these. I'm going to have a couple of beers and a banana nut muffin.(Laughter)I don't want to feel these. And I know that's knowing laughter. I hack into your lives for a living. God.(Laughter)You can't numb those hard feelings without numbing the other affects, our emotions. You cannot selectively numb. So when we numb those, we numb joy, we numb gratitude, we numb happiness. And then, we are miserable, and we are looking for purpose and meaning, and then we feel vulnerable, so then we have a couple of beers and a banana nut muffin. And it becomes this dangerous cycle.One of the things that I think we need to think about is why and how we numb. And it doesn't just have to be addiction. The other thing we do is we make everything that's uncertain certain. Religion has gone from a belief in faith and mystery to certainty. "I'm right, you're wrong. Shut up." That's it. Just certain. The more afraid we are, the more vulnerable we are, the more afraid we are. This is what politics looks like today. There's no discourse anymore. There's no conversation. There's just blame. You know how blame is described in the research? A way to discharge pain and discomfort. We perfect. If there's anyone who wants their life to look like this, it would be me, but it doesn't work. Because what we do is we take fat from our butts and put it in our cheeks.(Laughter)Which just, I hope in 100 years, people will look back and go, "Wow."(Laughter)And we perfect, most dangerously, our children. Let me tell you what we think about children. They're hardwired for struggle when they get here. And when you hold those perfect little babies in your hand, our job is not to say, "Look at her, she's perfect. My job is just to keep her perfect — make sure she makes the tennis team by fifth grade and Yale by seventh." That's not our job. Our job is to look and say, "You know what? You're imperfect, and you're wired for struggle, but you are worthy of love and belonging." That's our job. Show me a generation of kids raised like that, and we'll end the problems, I think, that we see today. We pretend that what we do doesn't have an effect on people. We do that in our personal lives. We do that corporate — whether it's a bailout, an oil spill ... a recall. We pretend like what we're doing doesn't have a huge impact on other people. I would say to companies, this is not our first rodeo, people. We just need you to be authentic and real and say ... "We're sorry. We'll fix it."But there's another way, and I'll leave you with this. This is what I have found: To let ourselves be seen, deeply seen, vulnerably seen ... to love with our whole hearts, even though there's no guarantee — and that's really hard, and I can tell you as a parent, that's excruciatingly difficult — to practice gratitude and joy in those moments of terror, when we're wondering, "Can I love you this much? Can I believe in this this passionately? Can I be this fierce about this?" just to be able to stop and, instead of catastrophizing what might happen, to say, "I'm just so grateful, because to feel this vulnerable means I'm alive." And the last, which I think is probably the most important, is to believe that we're enough. Because when we work from a place, I believe, that says, "I'm enough" ... then we stop screaming and start listening, we're kinder and gentler to the people around us, and we're kinder and gentler to ourselves.That's all I have. Thank you.(Applause)
