00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:48.958
which is why mammography doesn't work as well in them.

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.958
And although breast density generally declines with age,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
up to a third of women

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
retain dense breast tissue

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:58.958
for years after menopause.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
So how do you know if your breasts are dense?

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
Well, you need to read the details

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
of your mammography report.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
Radiologists classify breast density

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
into four categories

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
based on the appearance of the tissue on a mammogram.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
If the breast is less than 25 percent dense,

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
that's called fatty-replaced.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
The next category

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
is scattered fibroglandular densities,

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
followed by heterogeneously dense

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
and extremely dense.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
And breasts that fall into these two categories

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
are considered dense.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
The problem with breast density

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
is that it's truly the wolf in sheep's clothing.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
Both tumors and dense breast tissue

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
appear white on a mammogram,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
and the X-ray often can't distinguish between the two.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
So it's easy to see this tumor

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
in the upper part of this fatty breast.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
But imagine how difficult it would be

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
to find that tumor in this dense breast.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
That's why mammograms find

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
over 80 percent of tumors in fatty breasts,

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
but as few as 40 percent in extremely dense breasts.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
Now it's bad enough that breast density

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
makes it hard to find a cancer,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
but it turns out

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
that it's also a powerful predictor

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
of your risk for breast cancer.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
It's a stronger risk factor

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
than having a mother or a sister with breast cancer.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
At the time my patient posed this question to me,

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
breast density was an obscure topic

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
in the radiology literature,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
and very few women having mammograms,

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
or the physicians ordering them,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
knew about this.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
But what else could I offer her?

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:35.958
Mammograms have been around since the 1960's,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
and it's changed very little.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
There have been surprisingly few innovations,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
until digital mammography was approved

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
in 2000.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
Digital mammography is still an X-ray of the breast,

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
but the images

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
can be stored and manipulated digitally,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
just like we can with a digital camera.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
The U.S. has invested

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
four billion dollars

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:01.958
converting to digital mammography equipment,

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
and what have we gained from that investment?

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:08.958
In a study funded by over 25 million taxpayer dollars,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
digital mammography was found

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
to be no better over all

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
than traditional mammography,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
and in fact, it was worse in older women.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
But it was better in one group,

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
and that was women under 50

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
who were pre-menopausal and had dense breasts,

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
and in those women,

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
digital mammography found twice as many cancers,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
but it still only found 60 percent.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
So digital mammography

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
has been a giant leap forward

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
for manufacturers

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
of digital mammography equipment,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
but it's been a very small step forward for

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
womankind.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
What about ultrasound?

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
Ultrasound generates more biopsies

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
that are unnecessary relative to other technologies,

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
so it's not widely used.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
And MRI is exquisitely sensitive for finding tumors,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
but it's also very expensive.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
If we think about disruptive technology,

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
we see an almost ubiquitous pattern

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
of the technology getting smaller and less expensive.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
Think about iPods compared to stereos.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
But it's the exact opposite in health care.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
The machines get ever bigger

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
and ever more expensive.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
Screening the average young woman with an MRI

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
is kind of like driving to the grocery store in a Hummer.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
It's just way too much equipment.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
One MRI scan

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
costs 10 times what a digital mammogram costs.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
And sooner or later, we're going to have to accept the fact

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
that health care innovation

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
can't always come at a much higher price.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
Malcolm Gladwell wrote an article in the New Yorker

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
on innovation,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
and he made the case that scientific discoveries

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:56.958
are rarely the product of one individual's genius.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
Rather, big ideas can be orchestrated,

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
if you can simply gather

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
people with different perspectives in a room

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
and get them to talk about things

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
that they don't ordinarily talk about.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
It's like the essence of TED.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
He quotes one innovator who says,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:16.958
"The only time a physician and a physicist get together

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
is when the physicist gets sick."

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
(Laughter)

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
This makes no sense,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
because physicians have all kinds of problems

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
that they don't realize have solutions.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
And physicists have all kinds of solutions for things

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
that they don't realize are problems.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
Now, take a look at this cartoon

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
that accompanied Gladwell's article,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
and tell me if you see something disturbing

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
about this depiction of innovative thinkers.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
(Laughter)

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:48.958
So if you will allow me a little creative license,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
I will tell you the story

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
of the serendipitous collision

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
of my patient's problem

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
with a physicist's solution.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
Shortly after her visit,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
I was introduced to a nuclear physicist

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
at Mayo

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
named Michael O'Conner,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
who was a specialist in cardiac imaging,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
something I had nothing to do with.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
And he happened to tell me

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
about a conference he'd just returned from in Israel,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
where they were talking about a new type of gamma detector.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
Now gamma imaging has been around for a long time

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
to image the heart,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
and it had even been tried to image the breast.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
But the problem was

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
that the gamma detectors

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
were these huge, bulky tubes,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
and they were filled with these scintillating crystals,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
and you just couldn't get them close enough around the breast

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
to find small tumors.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
But the potential advantage was

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
that gamma rays, unlike X-rays,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
are not influenced by breast density.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
But this technology

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
could not find tumors when they're small,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
and finding a small tumor is critical for survival.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
If you can find a tumor

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
when it's less than a centimeter,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
survival exceeds 90 percent,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
but drops off rapidly

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
as tumor size increases.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
But Michael told me about

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
a new type of gamma detector that he'd seen,

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
and this is it.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
It's made

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
not of a bulky tube,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
but of a thin layer of a semiconductor material

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
that serves as the gamma detector.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
And I started talking to him

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
about this problem with breast density,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
and we realized that we might be able to get this detector

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
close enough around the breast

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
to actually find small tumors.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
So after putting together

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
a grid of these cubes with tape --

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
(Laughter)

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
-- Michael hacked off the X-ray plate

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
of a mammography machine

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
that was about to be thrown out,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
and we attached the new detector,

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
and we decided to call this machine

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
Molecular Breast Imaging, or MBI.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
This is an image from our first patient.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
And you can see, using the old gamma technology,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
that it just looked like noise.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
But using our new detector,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
we could begin to see the outline of a tumor.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
So here we were, a nuclear physicist,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
an internist,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
soon joined by Carrie Hruska, a biomedical engineer,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
and two radiologists,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
and we were trying to take on

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
the entrenched world of mammography

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
with a machine that was held together by duct tape.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
To say that we faced

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
high doses of skepticism

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
in those early years

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
is just a huge understatement,

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
but we were so convinced that we might be able to make this work

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
that we chipped away with incremental modifications

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
to this system.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
This is our current detector.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
And you can see that it looks a lot different.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
The duct tape is gone,

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
and we added a second detector on top of the breast,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
which has further improved our tumor detection.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
So how does this work?

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
The patient receives an injection of a radio tracer

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
that's taken up by rapidly proliferating tumor cells,

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
but not by normal cells,

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
and this is the key difference from mammography.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
Mammography relies on differences

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
in the appearance of the tumor from the background tissue,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
and we've seen that those differences

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
can be obscured in a dense breast.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
But MBI exploits

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
the different molecular behavior of tumors,

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:19.958
and therefore, it's impervious to breast density.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
After the injection,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
the patient's breast is placed between the detectors.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
And if you've ever had a mammogram --

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
if you're old enough to have had a mammogram --

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
you know what comes next:

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
pain.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
You may be surprised to know

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
that mammography is the only radiologic study

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
that's regulated by federal law,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
and the law requires

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
that the equivalent of a 40-pound car battery

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
come down on your breast during this study.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
But with MBI,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
we use just light, pain-free compression.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:59.958
(Applause)

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
And the detector

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
then transmits the image to the computer.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
So here's an example.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
You can see, on the right, a mammogram

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
showing a faint tumor,

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
the edges of which are blurred by the dense tissue.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
But the MBI image shows that tumor much more clearly,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
as well as a second tumor,

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
which profoundly influence that patient's surgical options.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
In this example, although the mammogram found one tumor,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
we were able to demonstrate three discrete tumors --

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
one is small as three millimeters.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
Our big break came in 2004.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
After we had demonstrated that we could find small tumors,

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
we used these images

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
to submit a grant to the Susan G. Komen Foundation.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
And we were elated when they took a chance

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
on a team of completely unknown investigators

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
and funded us to study

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
1,000 women with dense breasts,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
comparing a screening mammogram to an MBI.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
Of the tumors that we found,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
mammography found

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
only 25 percent of those tumors.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
MBI found 83 percent.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
Here's an example from that screening study.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
The digital mammogram was read as normal

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
and shows lots of dense tissue,

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
but the MBI shows an area of intense uptake,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
which correlated with a two-centimeter tumor.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
In this case, a one-centimeter tumor.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
And in this case,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
a 45-year-old medical secretary at Mayo,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
who had lost her mother to breast cancer when she was very young,

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
wanted to enroll in our study.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
And her mammogram showed an area of very dense tissue,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
but her MBI showed an area

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
of worrisome uptake,

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
which we can also see on a color image.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
And this corresponded

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
to a tumor the size of a golf ball.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
But fortunately it was removed

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
before it had spread to her lymph nodes.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
So now that we knew that this technology

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
could find three times more tumors in a dense breast,

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
we had to solve one very important problem.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
We had to figure out how to lower the radiation dose,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
and we have spent the last three years

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
making modifications to every aspect of the imaging system

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
to allow this.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
And I'm very happy to report that we're now using a dose of radiation

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
that is equivalent to the effective dose

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
from one digital mammogram.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
And at this low dose, we're continuing this screening study,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.958
and this image from three weeks ago

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
in a 67-year-old woman

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
shows a normal digital mammogram,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
but an MBI image

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
showing an uptake that proved to be a large cancer.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
So this is not just young women that it's benefiting.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
It's also older women with dense tissue.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
And we're now routinely using one-fifth the radiation dose

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
that's used in any other type of gamma technology.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
MBI generates four images per breast.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:50.958
MRI generates over a thousand.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
It takes a radiologist

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
years of specialty training

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
to become expert in differentiating

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
the normal anatomic detail

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
from the worrisome finding.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
But I suspect even the non-radiologists in the room

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
can find the tumor on the MBI image.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
But this is why MBI

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
is so potentially disruptive --

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
it's as accurate as MRI,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
it's far less complex to interpret,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
and it's a fraction of the cost.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
But you can understand why there may be

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
forces in the breast-imaging world

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
who prefer the status quo.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
After achieving what we felt were remarkable results,

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
our manuscript was rejected

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
by four journals.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
After the fourth rejection,

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
we requested reconsideration of the manuscript,

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
because we strongly suspected

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
that one of the reviewers who had rejected it

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
had a financial conflict of interest

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
in a competing technology.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
Our manuscript was then accepted

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:51.958
and will be published later this month

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
in the journal Radiology.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:17:01.958
(Applause)

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
We still need to complete the screening study using the low dose,

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
and then our findings will need to be replicated

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
at other institutions,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:11.958
and this could take five or more years.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
If this technology is widely adopted,

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:17.958
I will not benefit financially in any way,

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:20.958
and that is very important to me,

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:23.958
because it allows me to continue to tell you the truth.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
But I recognize --

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:30.958
(Applause)

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
I recognize that the adoption of this technology

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
will depend as much on economic

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
and political forces

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:40.958
as it will on the soundness of the science.

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:43.958
The MBI unit has now been FDA approved,

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:46.958
but it's not yet widely available.

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:48.958
So until something is available

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:50.958
for women with dense breasts,

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:52.958
there are things that you should know

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:54.958
to protect yourself.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:56.958
First, know your density.

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:58.958
Ninety percent of women don't,

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:00.958
and 95 percent of women don't know

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:03.958
that it increases your breast cancer risk.

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:06.958
The State of Connecticut became the first and only state

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:08.958
to mandate that women receive notification

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
of their breast density

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:13.958
after a mammogram.

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:16.958
I was at a conference of 60,000 people in breast-imaging

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:18.958
last week in Chicago,

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:21.958
and I was stunned that there was a heated debate

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:23.958
as to whether we should be telling women

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:25.958
what their breast density is.

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:27.958
Of course we should.

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:30.958
And if you don't know, please ask your doctor

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:33.958
or read the details of your mammography report.

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:35.958
Second, if you're pre-menopausal,

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:37.958
try to schedule your mammogram

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
in the first two weeks of your menstrual cycle,

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:42.958
when breast density is relatively lower.

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:45.958
Third, if you notice a persistent change in your breast,

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:48.958
insist on additional imaging.

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:50.958
And fourth and most important,

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:53.958
the mammography debate will rage on,

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:56.958
but I do believe that all women 40 and older

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:58.958
should have an annual mammogram.

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:00.958
Mammography isn't perfect,

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:02.958
but it's the only test that's been proven

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:05.958
to reduce mortality from breast cancer.

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:07.958
But this mortality banner

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
is the very sword

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:12.958
which mammography's most ardent advocates use

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:14.958
to deter innovation.

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:17.958
Some women who develop breast cancer

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:19.958
die from it many years later,

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:21.958
and most women, thankfully, survive.

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:23.958
So it takes 10 or more years

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:25.958
for any screening method

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:27.958
to demonstrate a reduction

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:29.958
in mortality from breast cancer.

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:31.958
Mammography's the only one that's been around long enough

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:34.958
to have a chance of making that claim.

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:37.958
It is time for us to accept

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:39.958
both the extraordinary successes of mammography

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:41.958
and the limitations.

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:43.958
We need to individualize screening

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:45.958
based on density.

00:19:45.958 --> 00:19:47.958
For women without dense breasts,

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:50.958
mammography is the best choice.

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:52.958
But for women with dense breasts;

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:54.958
we shouldn't abandon screening altogether,

00:19:54.958 --> 00:19:57.958
we need to offer them something better.

00:19:59.958 --> 00:20:01.958
The babies that we were carrying

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:04.958
when my patient first asked me this question

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:07.958
are now both in middle school,

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:10.958
and the answer has been so slow to come.

00:20:12.958 --> 00:20:14.958
She's given me her blessing

00:20:14.958 --> 00:20:17.958
to share this story with you.

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:19.958
After undergoing biopsies

00:20:19.958 --> 00:20:22.958
that further increased her risk for cancer

00:20:22.958 --> 00:20:24.958
and losing her sister to cancer,

00:20:24.958 --> 00:20:26.958
she made the difficult decision

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:29.958
to have a prophylactic mastectomy.

00:20:30.958 --> 00:20:33.958
We can and must do better,

00:20:33.958 --> 00:20:36.958
not just in time for her granddaughters

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:38.958
and my daughters,

00:20:38.958 --> 00:20:40.958
but in time for you.

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:42.958
Thank you.

00:20:42.958 --> 00:20:58.958
(Applause)

title: The 3 A's of awesome
transcript: So the Awesome story: It begins about 40 years ago, when my mom and my dad came to Canada. My mom left Nairobi, Kenya. My dad left a small village outside of Amritsar, India. And they got here in the late 1960s. They settled in a shady suburb about an hour east of Toronto, and they settled into a new life. They saw their first dentist, they ate their first hamburger, and they had their first kids. My sister and I grew up here, and we had quiet, happy childhoods. We had close family, good friends, a quiet street. We grew up taking for granted a lot of the things that my parents couldn't take for granted when they grew up — things like power always on in our houses, things like schools across the street and hospitals down the road and popsicles in the backyard. We grew up, and we grew older. I went to high school. I graduated. I moved out of the house, I got a job, I found a girl, I settled down — and I realize it sounds like a bad sitcom or a Cat Stevens' song —(Laughter)but life was pretty good. Life was pretty good. 2006 was a great year. Under clear blue skies in July in the wine region of Ontario, I got married, surrounded by 150 family and friends. 2007 was a great year. I graduated from school, and I went on a road trip with two of my closest friends. Here's a picture of me and my friend, Chris, on the coast of the Pacific Ocean. We actually saw seals out of our car window, and we pulled over to take a quick picture of them and then blocked them with our giant heads. (Laughter) So you can't actually see them, but it was breathtaking, believe me.(Laughter)2008 and 2009 were a little tougher. I know that they were tougher for a lot of people, not just me. First of all, the news was so heavy. It's still heavy now, and it was heavy before that, but when you flipped open a newspaper, when you turned on the TV, it was about ice caps melting, wars going on around the world, earthquakes, hurricanes and an economy that was wobbling on the brink of collapse, and then eventually did collapse, and so many of us losing our homes, or our jobs, or our retirements, or our livelihoods. 2008, 2009 were heavy years for me for another reason, too. I was going through a lot of personal problems at the time. My marriage wasn't going well, and we just were growing further and further apart. One day my wife came home from work and summoned the courage, through a lot of tears, to have a very honest conversation. And she said, "I don't love you anymore," and it was one of the most painful things I'd ever heard and certainly the most heartbreaking thing I'd ever heard, until only a month later, when I heard something even more heartbreaking.My friend Chris, who I just showed you a picture of, had been battling mental illness for some time. And for those of you whose lives have been touched by mental illness, you know how challenging it can be. I spoke to him on the phone at 10:30 p.m. on a Sunday night. We talked about the TV show we watched that evening. And Monday morning, I found out that he disappeared. Very sadly, he took his own life. And it was a really heavy time.And as these dark clouds were circling me, and I was finding it really, really difficult to think of anything good, I said to myself that I really needed a way to focus on the positive somehow. So I came home from work one night, and I logged onto the computer, and I started up a tiny website called 1000awesomethings.com. I was trying to remind myself of the simple, universal, little pleasures that we all love, but we just don't talk about enough — things like waiters and waitresses who bring you free refills without asking, being the first table to get called up to the dinner buffet at a wedding, wearing warm underwear from just out of the dryer, or when cashiers open up a new check-out lane at the grocery store and you get to be first in line — even if you were last at the other line, swoop right in there.(Laughter)And slowly over time, I started putting myself in a better mood. I mean, 50,000 blogs are started a day, and so my blog was just one of those 50,000. And nobody read it except for my mom. Although I should say that my traffic did skyrocket and go up by 100 percent when she forwarded it to my dad. (Laughter) And then I got excited when it started getting tens of hits, and then I started getting excited when it started getting dozens and then hundreds and then thousands and then millions. It started getting bigger and bigger and bigger. And then I got a phone call, and the voice at the other end of the line said, "You've just won the Best Blog In the World award." I was like, that sounds totally fake. (Laughter) (Applause) Which African country do you want me to wire all my money to? (Laughter) But it turns out, I jumped on a plane, and I ended up walking a red carpet between Sarah Silverman and Jimmy Fallon and Martha Stewart. And I went onstage to accept a Webby award for Best Blog. And the surprise and just the amazement of that was only overshadowed by my return to Toronto, when, in my inbox, 10 literary agents were waiting for me to talk about putting this into a book. Flash-forward to the next year and "The Book of Awesome" has now been number one on the bestseller list for 20 straight weeks.(Applause)But look, I said I wanted to do three things with you today. I said I wanted to tell you the Awesome story, I wanted to share with you the three As of Awesome, and I wanted to leave you with a closing thought. So let's talk about those three As. Over the last few years, I haven't had that much time to really think. But lately I have had the opportunity to take a step back and ask myself: "What is it over the last few years that helped me grow my website, but also grow myself?" And I've summarized those things, for me personally, as three As. They are Attitude, Awareness and Authenticity. I'd love to just talk about each one briefly.So Attitude: Look, we're all going to get lumps, and we're all going to get bumps. None of us can predict the future, but we do know one thing about it and that's that it ain't gonna go according to plan. We will all have high highs and big days and proud moments of smiles on graduation stages, father-daughter dances at weddings and healthy babies screeching in the delivery room, but between those high highs, we may also have some lumps and some bumps too. It's sad, and it's not pleasant to talk about, but your husband might leave you, your girlfriend could cheat, your headaches might be more serious than you thought, or your dog could get hit by a car on the street. It's not a happy thought, but your kids could get mixed up in gangs or bad scenes. Your mom could get cancer, your dad could get mean. And there are times in life when you will be tossed in the well, too, with twists in your stomach and with holes in your heart, and when that bad news washes over you, and when that pain sponges and soaks in, I just really hope you feel like you've always got two choices. One, you can swirl and twirl and gloom and doom forever, or two, you can grieve and then face the future with newly sober eyes. Having a great attitude is about choosing option number two, and choosing, no matter how difficult it is, no matter what pain hits you, choosing to move forward and move on and take baby steps into the future.The second "A" is Awareness. I love hanging out with three year-olds. I love the way that they see the world, because they're seeing the world for the first time. I love the way that they can stare at a bug crossing the sidewalk. I love the way that they'll stare slack-jawed at their first baseball game with wide eyes and a mitt on their hand, soaking in the crack of the bat and the crunch of the peanuts and the smell of the hotdogs. I love the way that they'll spend hours picking dandelions in the backyard and putting them into a nice centerpiece for Thanksgiving dinner. I love the way that they see the world, because they're seeing the world for the first time. Having a sense of awareness is just about embracing your inner three year-old. Because you all used to be three years old. That three-year-old boy is still part of you. That three-year-old girl is still part of you. They're in there. And being aware is just about remembering that you saw everything you've seen for the first time once, too. So there was a time when it was your first time ever hitting a string of green lights on the way home from work. There was the first time you walked by the open door of a bakery and smelt the bakery air, or the first time you pulled a 20-dollar bill out of your old jacket pocket and said, "Found money."The last "A" is Authenticity. And for this one, I want to tell you a quick story. Let's go all the way back to 1932 when, on a peanut farm in Georgia, a little baby boy named Roosevelt Grier was born. Roosevelt Grier, or Rosey Grier, as people used to call him, grew up and grew into a 300-pound, six-foot-five linebacker in the NFL. He's number 76 in the picture. Here he is pictured with the "fearsome foursome." These were four guys on the L.A. Rams in the 1960s you did not want to go up against. They were tough football players doing what they love, which was crushing skulls and separating shoulders on the football field. But Rosey Grier also had another passion. In his deeply authentic self, he also loved needlepoint. (Laughter) He loved knitting. He said that it calmed him down, it relaxed him, it took away his fear of flying and helped him meet chicks. That's what he said. I mean, he loved it so much that, after he retired from the NFL, he started joining clubs. And he even put out a book called "Rosey Grier's Needlepoint for Men." (Laughter) (Applause) It's a great cover. If you notice, he's actually needlepointing his own face.(Laughter)And so what I love about this story is that Rosey Grier is just such an authentic person, and that's what authenticity is all about. It's just about being you and being cool with that. And I think when you're authentic, you end up following your heart, and you put yourself in places and situations and in conversations that you love and that you enjoy. You meet people that you like talking to. You go places you've dreamt about. And you end you end up following your heart and feeling very fulfilled. So those are the three A's.For the closing thought, I want to take you all the way back to my parents coming to Canada. I don't know what it would feel like coming to a new country when you're in your mid-20s. I don't know, because I never did it, but I would imagine that it would take a great attitude. I would imagine that you'd have to be pretty aware of your surroundings and appreciating the small wonders that you're starting to see in your new world. And I think you'd have to be really authentic, you'd have to be really true to yourself in order to get through what you're being exposed to.I'd like to pause my TEDTalk for about 10 seconds right now, because you don't get many opportunities in life to do something like this, and my parents are sitting in the front row. So I wanted to ask them to, if they don't mind, stand up. And I just wanted to say thank you to you guys.(Applause)When I was growing up, my dad used to love telling the story of his first day in Canada. And it's a great story, because what happened was he got off the plane at the Toronto airport, and he was welcomed by a non-profit group, which I'm sure someone in this room runs. (Laughter) And this non-profit group had a big welcoming lunch for all the new immigrants to Canada. And my dad says he got off the plane and he went to this lunch and there was this huge spread. There was bread, there was those little, mini dill pickles, there was olives, those little white onions. There was rolled up turkey cold cuts, rolled up ham cold cuts, rolled up roast beef cold cuts and little cubes of cheese. There was tuna salad sandwiches and egg salad sandwiches and salmon salad sandwiches. There was lasagna, there was casseroles, there was brownies, there was butter tarts, and there was pies, lots and lots of pies. And when my dad tells the story, he says, "The craziest thing was, I'd never seen any of that before, except bread. (Laughter) I didn't know what was meat, what was vegetarian. I was eating olives with pie. (Laughter) I just couldn't believe how many things you can get here."(Laughter)When I was five years old, my dad used to take me grocery shopping, and he would stare in wonder at the little stickers that are on the fruits and vegetables. He would say, "Look, can you believe they have a mango here from Mexico? They've got an apple here from South Africa. Can you believe they've got a date from Morocco?" He's like, "Do you know where Morocco even is?" And I'd say, "I'm five. I don't even know where I am. Is this A&P?" And he'd say, "I don't know where Morocco is either, but let's find out." And so we'd buy the date, and we'd go home. And we'd actually take an atlas off the shelf, and we'd flip through until we found this mysterious country. And when we did, my dad would say, "Can you believe someone climbed a tree over there, picked this thing off it, put it in a truck, drove it all the way to the docks and then sailed it all the way across the Atlantic Ocean and then put it in another truck and drove that all the way to a tiny grocery store just outside our house, so they could sell it to us for 25 cents?" And I'd say, "I don't believe that." And he's like, "I don't believe it either. Things are amazing. There's just so many things to be happy about."When I stop to think about it, he's absolutely right. There are so many things to be happy about. We are the only species on the only life-giving rock in the entire universe that we've ever seen, capable of experiencing so many of these things. I mean, we're the only ones with architecture and agriculture. We're the only ones with jewelry and democracy. We've got airplanes, highway lanes, interior design and horoscope signs. We've got fashion magazines, house party scenes. You can watch a horror movie with monsters. You can go to a concert and hear guitars jamming. We've got books, buffets and radio waves, wedding brides and rollercoaster rides. You can sleep in clean sheets. You can go to the movies and get good seats. You can smell bakery air, walk around with rain hair, pop bubble wrap or take an illegal nap.We've got all that, but we've only got 100 years to enjoy it. And that's the sad part. The cashiers at your grocery store, the foreman at your plant, the guy tailgating you home on the highway, the telemarketer calling you during dinner, every teacher you've ever had, everyone that's ever woken up beside you, every politician in every country, every actor in every movie, every single person in your family, everyone you love, everyone in this room and you will be dead in a hundred years. Life is so great that we only get such a short time to experience and enjoy all those tiny little moments that make it so sweet. And that moment is right now, and those moments are counting down, and those moments are always, always, always fleeting.You will never be as young as you are right now. And that's why I believe that if you live your life with a great attitude, choosing to move forward and move on whenever life deals you a blow, living with a sense of awareness of the world around you, embracing your inner three year-old and seeing the tiny joys that make life so sweet and being authentic to yourself, being you and being cool with that, letting your heart lead you and putting yourself in experiences that satisfy you, then I think you'll live a life that is rich and is satisfying, and I think you'll live a life that is truly awesome.Thank you.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
So the Awesome story:

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:15.958
It begins about 40 years ago,

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:18.958
when my mom and my dad came to Canada.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:20.958
My mom left Nairobi, Kenya.

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
My dad left a small village outside of Amritsar, India.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:26.958
And they got here in the late 1960s.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
They settled in a shady suburb about an hour east of Toronto,

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.958
and they settled into a new life.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:33.958
They saw their first dentist,

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:35.958
they ate their first hamburger,

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:37.958
and they had their first kids.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
My sister and I

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
grew up here,

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:44.958
and we had quiet, happy childhoods.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:46.958
We had close family,

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.958
good friends, a quiet street.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.958
We grew up taking for granted

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
a lot of the things that my parents couldn't take for granted

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:54.958
when they grew up --

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
things like power always on

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:58.958
in our houses,

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
things like schools across the street

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:02.958
and hospitals down the road

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.958
and popsicles in the backyard.

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:06.958
We grew up, and we grew older.

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:08.958
I went to high school.

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:10.958
I graduated.

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:12.958
I moved out of the house, I got a job,

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:15.958
I found a girl, I settled down --

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
and I realize it sounds like a bad sitcom or a Cat Stevens' song --

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
(Laughter)

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
but life was pretty good.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
Life was pretty good.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:27.958
2006 was a great year.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:30.958
Under clear blue skies in July in the wine region of Ontario,

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
I got married,

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:35.958
surrounded by 150 family and friends.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
2007 was a great year.

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
I graduated from school,

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
and I went on a road trip with two of my closest friends.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:47.958
Here's a picture of me and my friend, Chris,

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
on the coast of the Pacific Ocean.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
We actually saw seals out of our car window,

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:53.958
and we pulled over to take a quick picture of them

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
and then blocked them with our giant heads.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
(Laughter)

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
So you can't actually see them,

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
but it was breathtaking,

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
believe me.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
(Laughter)

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
2008 and 2009 were a little tougher.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
I know that they were tougher for a lot of people,

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
not just me.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
First of all, the news was so heavy.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
It's still heavy now, and it was heavy before that,

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:21.958
but when you flipped open a newspaper, when you turned on the TV,

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:23.958
it was about ice caps melting,

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
wars going on around the world,

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:28.958
earthquakes, hurricanes

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:31.958
and an economy that was wobbling on the brink of collapse,

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
and then eventually did collapse,

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
and so many of us losing our homes,

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
or our jobs,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
or our retirements,

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
or our livelihoods.

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
2008, 2009 were heavy years for me for another reason, too.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
I was going through a lot of personal problems at the time.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:52.958
My marriage wasn't going well,

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:56.958
and we just were growing further and further apart.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
One day my wife came home from work

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
and summoned the courage, through a lot of tears,

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
to have a very honest conversation.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
And she said, "I don't love you anymore,"

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:11.958
and it was one of the most painful things I'd ever heard

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
and certainly the most heartbreaking thing I'd ever heard,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:16.958
until only a month later,

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.958
when I heard something even more heartbreaking.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
My friend Chris, who I just showed you a picture of,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
had been battling mental illness for some time.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
And for those of you

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
whose lives have been touched by mental illness,

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
you know how challenging it can be.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
I spoke to him on the phone at 10:30 p.m.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
on a Sunday night.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
We talked about the TV show we watched that evening.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
And Monday morning, I found out that he disappeared.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
Very sadly, he took his own life.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
And it was a really heavy time.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
And as these dark clouds were circling me,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
and I was finding it really, really difficult

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
to think of anything good,

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
I said to myself that I really needed a way

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
to focus on the positive somehow.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
So I came home from work one night,

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
and I logged onto the computer,

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
and I started up a tiny website

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:09.958
called 1000awesomethings.com.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
I was trying to remind myself

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
of the simple, universal, little pleasures that we all love,

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
but we just don't talk about enough --

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
things like waiters and waitresses

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
who bring you free refills without asking,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
being the first table to get called up

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
to the dinner buffet at a wedding,

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
wearing warm underwear from just out of the dryer,

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
or when cashiers open up a new check-out lane at the grocery store

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
and you get to be first in line --

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
even if you were last at the other line, swoop right in there.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.958
(Laughter)

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
And slowly over time,

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
I started putting myself in a better mood.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
I mean, 50,000 blogs

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
are started a day,

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
and so my blog was just one of those 50,000.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
And nobody read it except for my mom.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
Although I should say that my traffic did skyrocket

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
and go up by 100 percent

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
when she forwarded it to my dad.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
(Laughter)

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
And then I got excited

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
when it started getting tens of hits,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
and then I started getting excited when it started getting dozens

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
and then hundreds and then thousands

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
and then millions.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
It started getting bigger and bigger and bigger.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
And then I got a phone call,

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
and the voice at the other end of the line said,

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:23.958
"You've just won the Best Blog In the World award."

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
I was like, that sounds totally fake.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
(Laughter)

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:33.958
(Applause)

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
Which African country do you want me to wire all my money to?

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
(Laughter)

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
But it turns out, I jumped on a plane,

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
and I ended up walking a red carpet

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
between Sarah Silverman and Jimmy Fallon and Martha Stewart.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:49.958
And I went onstage to accept a Webby award for Best Blog.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
And the surprise

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
and just the amazement of that

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
was only overshadowed by my return to Toronto,

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
when, in my inbox,

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
10 literary agents were waiting for me

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
to talk about putting this into a book.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
Flash-forward to the next year

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
and "The Book of Awesome" has now been

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
number one on the bestseller list for 20 straight weeks.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:17.958
(Applause)

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
But look, I said I wanted to do three things with you today.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
I said I wanted to tell you the Awesome story,

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
I wanted to share with you the three As of Awesome,

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
and I wanted to leave you with a closing thought.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
So let's talk about those three As.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
Over the last few years,

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
I haven't had that much time to really think.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
But lately I have had the opportunity to take a step back

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
and ask myself: "What is it over the last few years

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
that helped me grow my website,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
but also grow myself?"

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
And I've summarized those things, for me personally,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
as three As.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
They are Attitude, Awareness

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
and Authenticity.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
I'd love to just talk about each one briefly.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
So Attitude:

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
Look, we're all going to get lumps,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
and we're all going to get bumps.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
None of us can predict the future, but we do know one thing about it

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
and that's that it ain't gonna go according to plan.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
We will all have high highs

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
and big days and proud moments

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
of smiles on graduation stages,

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
father-daughter dances at weddings

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
and healthy babies screeching in the delivery room,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
but between those high highs,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
we may also have some lumps and some bumps too.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
It's sad, and it's not pleasant to talk about,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
but your husband might leave you,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
your girlfriend could cheat,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
your headaches might be more serious than you thought,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:37.958
or your dog could get hit by a car on the street.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
It's not a happy thought,

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
but your kids could get mixed up in gangs

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
or bad scenes.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
Your mom could get cancer,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
your dad could get mean.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
And there are times in life

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
when you will be tossed in the well, too,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
with twists in your stomach and with holes in your heart,

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
and when that bad news washes over you,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
and when that pain sponges and soaks in,

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
I just really hope you feel

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
like you've always got two choices.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
One, you can swirl and twirl

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
and gloom and doom forever,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
or two, you can grieve

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
and then face the future

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
with newly sober eyes.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
Having a great attitude is about choosing option number two,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
and choosing, no matter how difficult it is,

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
no matter what pain hits you,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
choosing to move forward and move on

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
and take baby steps into the future.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
The second "A" is Awareness.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
I love hanging out with three year-olds.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
I love the way that they see the world,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
because they're seeing the world for the first time.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
I love the way that they can stare at a bug crossing the sidewalk.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
I love the way that they'll stare slack-jawed

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
at their first baseball game

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
with wide eyes and a mitt on their hand,

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
soaking in the crack of the bat and the crunch of the peanuts

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
and the smell of the hotdogs.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
I love the way that they'll spend hours picking dandelions in the backyard

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
and putting them into a nice centerpiece

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
for Thanksgiving dinner.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
I love the way that they see the world,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
because they're seeing the world

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
for the first time.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
Having a sense of awareness

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
is just about embracing your inner three year-old.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
Because you all used to be three years old.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
That three-year-old boy is still part of you.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
That three-year-old girl is still part of you.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
They're in there.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
And being aware is just about remembering

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
that you saw everything you've seen

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
for the first time once, too.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
So there was a time when it was your first time ever

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
hitting a string of green lights on the way home from work.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
There was the first time you walked by the open door of a bakery

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
and smelt the bakery air,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
or the first time you pulled a 20-dollar bill out of your old jacket pocket

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
and said, "Found money."

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
The last "A" is Authenticity.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
And for this one, I want to tell you a quick story.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
Let's go all the way back to 1932

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
when, on a peanut farm in Georgia,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
a little baby boy named Roosevelt Grier was born.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Roosevelt Grier, or Rosey Grier, as people used to call him,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
grew up and grew into

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:07.958
a 300-pound, six-foot-five linebacker in the NFL.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
He's number 76 in the picture.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
Here he is pictured with the "fearsome foursome."

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
These were four guys on the L.A. Rams in the 1960s

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
you did not want to go up against.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
They were tough football players doing what they love,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
which was crushing skulls

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
and separating shoulders on the football field.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
But Rosey Grier also had

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
another passion.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
In his deeply authentic self,

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
he also loved needlepoint. (Laughter)

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
He loved knitting.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
He said that it calmed him down, it relaxed him,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
it took away his fear of flying and helped him meet chicks.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
That's what he said.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
I mean, he loved it so much that, after he retired from the NFL,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
he started joining clubs.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
And he even put out a book

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
called "Rosey Grier's Needlepoint for Men."

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
(Laughter)

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
(Applause)

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
It's a great cover.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
If you notice, he's actually needlepointing his own face.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
(Laughter)

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
And so what I love about this story

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
is that Rosey Grier

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
is just such an authentic person,

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
and that's what authenticity is all about.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
It's just about being you and being cool with that.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
And I think when you're authentic,

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
you end up following your heart,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
and you put yourself in places

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
and situations and in conversations

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
that you love and that you enjoy.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
You meet people that you like talking to.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
You go places you've dreamt about.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
And you end you end up following your heart

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
and feeling very fulfilled.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
So those are the three A's.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
For the closing thought, I want to take you all the way back

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
to my parents coming to Canada.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
I don't know what it would feel like

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
coming to a new country when you're in your mid-20s.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
I don't know, because I never did it,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
but I would imagine that it would take a great attitude.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
I would imagine that you'd have to be pretty aware of your surroundings

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
and appreciating the small wonders

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
that you're starting to see in your new world.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
And I think you'd have to be really authentic,

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
you'd have to be really true to yourself

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
in order to get through what you're being exposed to.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
I'd like to pause my TEDTalk

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
for about 10 seconds right now,

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
because you don't get many opportunities in life to do something like this,

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
and my parents are sitting in the front row.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
So I wanted to ask them to, if they don't mind, stand up.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
And I just wanted to say thank you to you guys.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:41.958
(Applause)

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
When I was growing up, my dad used to love telling the story

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
of his first day in Canada.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
And it's a great story, because what happened was

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
he got off the plane at the Toronto airport,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
and he was welcomed by a non-profit group,

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
which I'm sure someone in this room runs.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
(Laughter)

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:01.958
And this non-profit group had a big welcoming lunch

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
for all the new immigrants to Canada.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
And my dad says he got off the plane and he went to this lunch

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
and there was this huge spread.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
There was bread, there was those little, mini dill pickles,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
there was olives, those little white onions.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
There was rolled up turkey cold cuts,

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
rolled up ham cold cuts, rolled up roast beef cold cuts

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
and little cubes of cheese.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
There was tuna salad sandwiches and egg salad sandwiches

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
and salmon salad sandwiches.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
There was lasagna, there was casseroles,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
there was brownies, there was butter tarts,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
and there was pies, lots and lots of pies.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
And when my dad tells the story, he says,

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:39.958
"The craziest thing was, I'd never seen any of that before, except bread.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
(Laughter)

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
I didn't know what was meat, what was vegetarian.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
I was eating olives with pie.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
(Laughter)

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
I just couldn't believe how many things you can get here."

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
(Laughter)

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
When I was five years old,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
my dad used to take me grocery shopping,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
and he would stare in wonder

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
at the little stickers that are on the fruits and vegetables.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
He would say, "Look, can you believe they have a mango here from Mexico?

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
They've got an apple here from South Africa.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
Can you believe they've got a date from Morocco?"

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
He's like, "Do you know where Morocco even is?"

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
And I'd say, "I'm five. I don't even know where I am.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
Is this A&P?"

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
And he'd say, "I don't know where Morocco is either, but let's find out."

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
And so we'd buy the date, and we'd go home.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And we'd actually take an atlas off the shelf,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
and we'd flip through until we found this mysterious country.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
And when we did, my dad would say,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
"Can you believe someone climbed a tree over there,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
picked this thing off it, put it in a truck,

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
drove it all the way to the docks

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
and then sailed it all the way

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
across the Atlantic Ocean

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
and then put it in another truck

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
and drove that all the way to a tiny grocery store just outside our house,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
so they could sell it to us for 25 cents?"

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
And I'd say, "I don't believe that."

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
And he's like, "I don't believe it either.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
Things are amazing. There's just so many things to be happy about."

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
When I stop to think about it, he's absolutely right.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
There are so many things to be happy about.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
We are the only species

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
on the only life-giving rock

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
in the entire universe that we've ever seen,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
capable of experiencing

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
so many of these things.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
I mean, we're the only ones with architecture and agriculture.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
We're the only ones with jewelry and democracy.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
We've got airplanes, highway lanes,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
interior design and horoscope signs.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
We've got fashion magazines, house party scenes.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
You can watch a horror movie with monsters.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
You can go to a concert and hear guitars jamming.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
We've got books, buffets and radio waves,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
wedding brides and rollercoaster rides.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
You can sleep in clean sheets.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
You can go to the movies and get good seats.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
You can smell bakery air, walk around with rain hair,

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
pop bubble wrap or take an illegal nap.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
We've got all that,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:53.958
but we've only got 100 years to enjoy it.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
And that's the sad part.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
The cashiers at your grocery store,

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
the foreman at your plant,

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
the guy tailgating you home on the highway,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
the telemarketer calling you during dinner,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
every teacher you've ever had,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
everyone that's ever woken up beside you,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
every politician in every country,

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
every actor in every movie,

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.958
every single person in your family, everyone you love,

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:25.958
everyone in this room and you

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
will be dead in a hundred years.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
Life is so great that we only get such a short time

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
to experience and enjoy

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
all those tiny little moments that make it so sweet.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
And that moment is right now,

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
and those moments are counting down,

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
and those moments are always, always, always fleeting.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:49.958
You will never be as young as you are right now.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:53.958
And that's why I believe that if you live your life

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:55.958
with a great attitude,

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:57.958
choosing to move forward and move on

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
whenever life deals you a blow,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
living with a sense of awareness of the world around you,

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
embracing your inner three year-old

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:07.958
and seeing the tiny joys that make life so sweet

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
and being authentic to yourself,

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
being you and being cool with that,

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
letting your heart lead you and putting yourself in experiences that satisfy you,

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
then I think you'll live a life

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
that is rich and is satisfying,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
and I think you'll live a life that is truly awesome.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
Thank you.

title: A realistic vision for world peace
transcript: I'm actually here to make a challenge to people. I know there have been many challenges made to people. The one I'm going to make is that it is time for us to reclaim what peace really means. Peace is not "Kumbaya, my Lord." Peace is not the dove and the rainbow — as lovely as they are. When I see the symbols of the rainbow and the dove, I think of personal serenity. I think of meditation. I do not think about what I consider to be peace, which is sustainable peace with justice and equality. It is a sustainable peace in which the majority of people on this planet have access to enough resources to live dignified lives, where these people have enough access to education and health care, so that they can live in freedom from want and freedom from fear. This is called human security. And I am not a complete pacifist like some of my really, really heavy-duty, non-violent friends, like Mairead McGuire. I understand that humans are so "messed up" — to use a nice word, because I promised my mom I'd stop using the F-bomb in public. And I'm trying harder and harder. Mom, I'm really trying.We need a little bit of police; we need a little bit of military, but for defense. We need to redefine what makes us secure in this world. It is not arming our country to the teeth. It is not getting other countries to arm themselves to the teeth with the weapons that we produce and we sell them. It is using that money more rationally to make the countries of the world secure, to make the people of the world secure. I was thinking about the recent ongoings in Congress, where the president is offering 8.4 billion dollars to try to get the START vote. I certainly support the START vote. But he's offering 84 billion dollars for the modernizing of nuclear weapons. Do you know the figure that the U.N. talks about for fulfilling the Millennium Development Goals is 80 billion dollars? Just that little bit of money, which to me, I wish it was in my bank account — it's not, but ... In global terms, it's a little bit of money. But it's going to modernize weapons we do not need and will not be gotten rid of in our lifetime, unless we get up off our ... and take action to make it happen, unless we begin to believe that all of the things that we've been hearing about in these last two days are elements of what come together to make human security. It is saving the tigers. It is stopping the tar sands. It is having access to medical equipment that can actually tell who does have cancer. It is all of those things. It is using our money for all of those things. It is about action.I was in Hiroshima a couple of weeks ago, and His Holiness — we're sitting there in front of thousands of people in the city, and there were about eight of us Nobel laureates. And he's a bad guy. He's like a bad kid in church. We're staring at everybody, waiting our turn to speak, and he leans over to me, and he says, "Jody, I'm a Buddhist monk." I said, "Yes, Your Holiness. Your robe gives it away." (Laughter) He said, "You know that I kind of like meditation, and I pray." I said, "That's good. That's good. We need that in the world. I don't follow that, but that's cool." And he says, "But I have become skeptical. I do not believe that meditation and prayer will change this world. I think what we need is action." His Holiness, in his robes, is my new action hero.I spoke with Aung Sun Suu Kyi a couple of days ago. As most of you know, she's a hero for democracy in her country, Burma. You probably also know that she has spent 15 of the last 20 years imprisoned for her efforts to bring about democracy. She was just released a couple of weeks ago, and we're very concerned to see how long she will be free, because she is already out in the streets in Rangoon, agitating for change. She is already out in the streets, working with the party to try to rebuild it. But I talked to her for a range of issues. But one thing that I want to say, because it's similar to what His Holiness said. She said, "You know, we have a long road to go to finally get democracy in my country. But I don't believe in hope without endeavor. I don't believe in the hope of change, unless we take action to make it so."Here's another woman hero of mine. She's my friend, Dr. Shirin Ebadi, the first Muslim woman to receive the Nobel Peace Prize. She has been in exile for the last year and a half. You ask her where she lives — where does she live in exile? She says the airports of the world. She is traveling because she was out of the country at the time of the elections. And instead of going home, she conferred with all the other women that she works with, who said to her, "Stay out. We need you out. We need to be able to talk to you out there, so that you can give the message of what's happening here." A year and a half — she's out speaking on behalf of the other women in her country.Wangari Maathai — 2004 Peace laureate. They call her the "Tree Lady," but she's more than the Tree Lady. Working for peace is very creative. It's hard work every day. When she was planting those trees, I don't think most people understand that, at the same time, she was using the action of getting people together to plant those trees to talk about how to overcome the authoritarian government in her country. People could not gather without getting busted and taken to jail. But if they were together planting trees for the environment, it was okay — creativity. But it's not just iconic women like Shirin, like Aung Sun Suu Kyi, like Wangari Maathai — it is other women in the world who are also struggling together to change this world.The Women's League of Burma, 11 individual organizations of Burmese women came together because there's strength in numbers. Working together is what changes our world. The Million Signatures Campaign of women inside Burma working together to change human rights, to bring democracy to that country. When one is arrested and taken to prison, another one comes out and joins the movement, recognizing that if they work together, they will ultimately bring change in their own country.Mairead McGuire in the middle, Betty Williams on the right-hand side — bringing peace to Northern Ireland. I'll tell you the quick story. An IRA driver was shot, and his car plowed into people on the side of the street. There was a mother and three children. The children were killed on the spot. It was Mairead's sister. Instead of giving in to grief, depression, defeat in the face of that violence, Mairead hooked up with Betty — a staunch Protestant and a staunch Catholic — and they took to the streets to say, "No more violence." And they were able to get tens of thousands of, primarily, women, some men, in the streets to bring about change. And they have been part of what brought peace to Northern Ireland, and they're still working on it, because there's still a lot more to do.This is Rigoberta Menchu Tum. She also received the Peace Prize. She is now running for president. She is educating the indigenous people of her country about what it means to be a democracy, about how you bring democracy to the country, about educating, about how to vote — but that democracy is not just about voting; it's about being an active citizen.That's what I got stuck doing — the landmine campaign. One of the things that made this campaign work is because we grew from two NGOs to thousands in 90 countries around the world, working together in common cause to ban landmines. Some of the people who worked in our campaign could only work maybe an hour a month. They could maybe volunteer that much. There were others, like myself, who were full-time. But it was the actions, together, of all of us that brought about that change.In my view, what we need today is people getting up and taking action to reclaim the meaning of peace. It's not a dirty word. It's hard work every single day. And if each of us who cares about the different things we care about got up off our butts and volunteered as much time as we could, we would change this world, we would save this world. And we can't wait for the other guy. We have to do it ourselves.Thank you.(Applause)
