00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:15.958
I will start by posing a little bit of a challenge:

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:18.958
the challenge of dealing with data,

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:20.958
data that we have to deal with

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:22.958
in medical situations.

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.958
It's really a huge challenge for us.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
And this is our beast of burden --

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:28.958
this is a Computer Tomography machine,

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:30.958
a CT machine.

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
It's a fantastic device.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
It uses X-rays, X-ray beams,

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
that are rotating very fast around the human body.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
It takes about 30 seconds to go through the whole machine

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
and is generating enormous amounts of information

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.958
that comes out of the machine.

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:45.958
So this is a fantastic machine

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
that we can use

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:49.958
for improving health care,

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:51.958
but as I said, it's also a challenge for us.

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:54.958
And the challenge is really found in this picture here.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
It's the medical data explosion

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:58.958
that we're having right now.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
We're facing this problem.

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:02.958
And let me step back in time.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
Let's go back a few years in time and see what happened back then.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
These machines that came out --

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
they started coming in the 1970s --

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
they would scan human bodies,

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:13.958
and they would generate about 100 images

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:15.958
of the human body.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:17.958
And I've taken the liberty, just for clarity,

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:20.958
to translate that to data slices.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
That would correspond to about 50 megabytes of data,

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
which is small

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:27.958
when you think about the data we can handle today

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
just on normal mobile devices.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
If you translate that to phone books,

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
it's about one meter of phone books in the pile.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
Looking at what we're doing today

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
with these machines that we have,

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
we can, just in a few seconds,

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
get 24,000 images out of a body,

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:45.958
and that would correspond to about 20 gigabytes of data,

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
or 800 phone books,

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
and the pile would then be 200 meters of phone books.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
What's about to happen --

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:53.958
and we're seeing this; it's beginning --

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:55.958
a technology trend that's happening right now

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
is that we're starting to look at time-resolved situations as well.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:01.958
So we're getting the dynamics out of the body as well.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:03.958
And just assume

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:06.958
that we will be collecting data during five seconds,

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:08.958
and that would correspond to one terabyte of data --

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:10.958
that's 800,000 books

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:12.958
and 16 kilometers of phone books.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:14.958
That's one patient, one data set.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
And this is what we have to deal with.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
So this is really the enormous challenge that we have.

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:22.958
And already today -- this is 25,000 images.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
Imagine the days

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
when we had radiologists doing this.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
They would put up 25,000 images,

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:31.958
they would go like this, "25,0000, okay, okay.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
There is the problem."

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
They can't do that anymore. That's impossible.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:38.958
So we have to do something that's a little bit more intelligent than doing this.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:41.958
So what we do is that we put all these slices together.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:44.958
Imagine that you slice your body in all these directions,

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.958
and then you try to put the slices back together again

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.958
into a pile of data, into a block of data.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
So this is really what we're doing.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:54.958
So this gigabyte or terabyte of data, we're putting it into this block.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
But of course, the block of data

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
just contains the amount of X-ray

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
that's been absorbed in each point in the human body.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
So what we need to do is to figure out a way

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
of looking at the things we do want to look at

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
and make things transparent that we don't want to look at.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
So transforming the data set

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
into something that looks like this.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
And this is a challenge.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
This is a huge challenge for us to do that.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
Using computers, even though they're getting faster and better all the time,

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.958
it's a challenge to deal with gigabytes of data,

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
terabytes of data

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
and extracting the relevant information.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
I want to look at the heart.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
I want to look at the blood vessels. I want to look at the liver.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
Maybe even find a tumor,

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
in some cases.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
So this is where this little dear comes into play.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
This is my daughter.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
This is as of 9 a.m. this morning.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
She's playing a computer game.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
She's only two years old,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
and she's having a blast.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
So she's really the driving force

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:53.958
behind the development of graphics-processing units.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
As long as kids are playing computer games,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
graphics is getting better and better and better.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
So please go back home, tell your kids to play more games,

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
because that's what I need.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
So what's inside of this machine

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
is what enables me to do the things that I'm doing

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
with the medical data.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
So really what I'm doing is using these fantastic little devices.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
And you know, going back

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
maybe 10 years in time

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
when I got the funding

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
to buy my first graphics computer --

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
it was a huge machine.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
It was cabinets of processors and storage and everything.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
I paid about one million dollars for that machine.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
That machine is, today, about as fast as my iPhone.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
So every month there are new graphics cards coming out,

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:38.958
and here is a few of the latest ones from the vendors --

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
NVIDIA, ATI, Intel is out there as well.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
And you know, for a few hundred bucks

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
you can get these things and put them into your computer,

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
and you can do fantastic things with these graphics cards.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
So this is really what's enabling us

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
to deal with the explosion of data in medicine,

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
together with some really nifty work

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
in terms of algorithms --

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
compressing data,

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
extracting the relevant information that people are doing research on.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
So I'm going to show you a few examples of what we can do.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
This is a data set that was captured using a CT scanner.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
You can see that this is a full data [set].

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
It's a woman. You can see the hair.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
You can see the individual structures of the woman.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
You can see that there is [a] scattering of X-rays

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
on the teeth, the metal in the teeth.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
That's where those artifacts are coming from.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
But fully interactively

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
on standard graphics cards on a normal computer,

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
I can just put in a clip plane.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
And of course all the data is inside,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
so I can start rotating, I can look at it from different angles,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
and I can see that this woman had a problem.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
She had a bleeding up in the brain,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
and that's been fixed with a little stent,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
a metal clamp that's tightening up the vessel.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
And just by changing the functions,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
then I can decide what's going to be transparent

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
and what's going to be visible.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
I can look at the skull structure,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
and I can see that, okay, this is where they opened up the skull on this woman,

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
and that's where they went in.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
So these are fantastic images.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
They're really high resolution,

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
and they're really showing us what we can do

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
with standard graphics cards today.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
Now we have really made use of this,

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
and we have tried to squeeze a lot of data

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
into the system.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
And one of the applications that we've been working on --

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
and this has gotten a little bit of traction worldwide --

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
is the application of virtual autopsies.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
So again, looking at very, very large data sets,

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
and you saw those full-body scans that we can do.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
We're just pushing the body through the whole CT scanner,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
and just in a few seconds we can get a full-body data set.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
So this is from a virtual autopsy.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
And you can see how I'm gradually peeling off.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
First you saw the body bag that the body came in,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
then I'm peeling off the skin -- you can see the muscles --

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
and eventually you can see the bone structure of this woman.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
Now at this point, I would also like to emphasize

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
that, with the greatest respect

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
for the people that I'm now going to show --

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
I'm going to show you a few cases of virtual autopsies --

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
so it's with great respect for the people

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
that have died under violent circumstances

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
that I'm showing these pictures to you.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
In the forensic case --

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
and this is something

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
that ... there's been approximately 400 cases so far

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
just in the part of Sweden that I come from

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
that has been undergoing virtual autopsies

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
in the past four years.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
So this will be the typical workflow situation.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
The police will decide --

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
in the evening, when there's a case coming in --

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
they will decide, okay, is this a case where we need to do an autopsy?

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
So in the morning, in between six and seven in the morning,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
the body is then transported inside of the body bag

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
to our center

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
and is being scanned through one of the CT scanners.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
And then the radiologist, together with the pathologist

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
and sometimes the forensic scientist,

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
looks at the data that's coming out,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
and they have a joint session.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
And then they decide what to do in the real physical autopsy after that.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
Now looking at a few cases,

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
here's one of the first cases that we had.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
You can really see the details of the data set.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
It's very high-resolution,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
and it's our algorithms that allow us

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
to zoom in on all the details.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
And again, it's fully interactive,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
so you can rotate and you can look at things in real time

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
on these systems here.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
Without saying too much about this case,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
this is a traffic accident,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
a drunk driver hit a woman.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
And it's very, very easy to see the damages on the bone structure.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
And the cause of death is the broken neck.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
And this women also ended up under the car,

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
so she's quite badly beaten up

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
by this injury.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
Here's another case, a knifing.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
And this is also again showing us what we can do.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
It's very easy to look at metal artifacts

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
that we can show inside of the body.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
You can also see some of the artifacts from the teeth --

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
that's actually the filling of the teeth --

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
but because I've set the functions to show me metal

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
and make everything else transparent.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
Here's another violent case. This really didn't kill the person.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
The person was killed by stabs in the heart,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
but they just deposited the knife

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
by putting it through one of the eyeballs.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
Here's another case.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
It's very interesting for us

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
to be able to look at things like knife stabbings.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
Here you can see that knife went through the heart.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
It's very easy to see how air has been leaking

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
from one part to another part,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
which is difficult to do in a normal, standard, physical autopsy.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
So it really, really helps

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
the criminal investigation

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
to establish the cause of death,

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
and in some cases also directing the investigation in the right direction

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
to find out who the killer really was.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
Here's another case that I think is interesting.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
Here you can see a bullet

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
that has lodged just next to the spine on this person.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
And what we've done is that we've turned the bullet into a light source,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
so that bullet is actually shining,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
and it makes it really easy to find these fragments.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
During a physical autopsy,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
if you actually have to dig through the body to find these fragments,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
that's actually quite hard to do.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
One of the things that I'm really, really happy

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
to be able to show you here today

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
is our virtual autopsy table.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
It's a touch device that we have developed

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
based on these algorithms, using standard graphics GPUs.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
It actually looks like this,

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
just to give you a feeling for what it looks like.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
It really just works like a huge iPhone.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
So we've implemented

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
all the gestures you can do on the table,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:13.958
and you can think of it as an enormous touch interface.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
So if you were thinking of buying an iPad,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
forget about it. This is what you want instead.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
Steve, I hope you're listening to this, all right.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
So it's a very nice little device.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
So if you have the opportunity, please try it out.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
It's really a hands-on experience.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
So it gained some traction, and we're trying to roll this out

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
and trying to use it for educational purposes,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
but also, perhaps in the future,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
in a more clinical situation.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
There's a YouTube video that you can download and look at this,

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
if you want to convey the information to other people

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
about virtual autopsies.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
Okay, now that we're talking about touch,

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
let me move on to really "touching" data.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
And this is a bit of science fiction now,

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
so we're moving into really the future.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
This is not really what the medical doctors are using right now,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
but I hope they will in the future.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
So what you're seeing on the left is a touch device.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
It's a little mechanical pen

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
that has very, very fast step motors inside of the pen.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
And so I can generate a force feedback.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
So when I virtually touch data,

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
it will generate forces in the pen, so I get a feedback.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
So in this particular situation,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
it's a scan of a living person.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
I have this pen, and I look at the data,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
and I move the pen towards the head,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
and all of a sudden I feel resistance.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
So I can feel the skin.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
If I push a little bit harder, I'll go through the skin,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
and I can feel the bone structure inside.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
If I push even harder, I'll go through the bone structure,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
especially close to the ear where the bone is very soft.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
And then I can feel the brain inside, and this will be the slushy like this.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
So this is really nice.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
And to take that even further, this is a heart.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
And this is also due to these fantastic new scanners,

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
that just in 0.3 seconds,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
I can scan the whole heart,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
and I can do that with time resolution.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
So just looking at this heart,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
I can play back a video here.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
And this is Karljohan, one of my graduate students

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
who's been working on this project.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
And he's sitting there in front of the Haptic device, the force feedback system,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
and he's moving his pen towards the heart,

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
and the heart is now beating in front of him,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
so he can see how the heart is beating.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
He's taken the pen, and he's moving it towards the heart,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
and he's putting it on the heart,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
and then he feels the heartbeats from the real living patient.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
Then he can examine how the heart is moving.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
He can go inside, push inside of the heart,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
and really feel how the valves are moving.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
And this, I think, is really the future for heart surgeons.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
I mean it's probably the wet dream for a heart surgeon

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
to be able to go inside of the patient's heart

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
before you actually do surgery,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
and do that with high-quality resolution data.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
So this is really neat.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.958
Now we're going even further into science fiction.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
And we heard a little bit about functional MRI.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
Now this is really an interesting project.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
MRI is using magnetic fields

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
and radio frequencies

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
to scan the brain, or any part of the body.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
So what we're really getting out of this

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
is information of the structure of the brain,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
but we can also measure the difference

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
in magnetic properties of blood that's oxygenated

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
and blood that's depleted of oxygen.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
That means that it's possible

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
to map out the activity of the brain.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
So this is something that we've been working on.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
And you just saw Motts the research engineer, there,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
going into the MRI system,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
and he was wearing goggles.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
So he could actually see things in the goggles.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
So I could present things to him while he's in the scanner.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
And this is a little bit freaky,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
because what Motts is seeing is actually this.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
He's seeing his own brain.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
So Motts is doing something here,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
and probably he is going like this with his right hand,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
because the left side is activated

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
on the motor cortex.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
And then he can see that at the same time.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
These visualizations are brand new.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
And this is something that we've been researching for a little while.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
This is another sequence of Motts' brain.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And here we asked Motts to calculate backwards from 100.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
So he's going "100, 97, 94."

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
And then he's going backwards.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
And you can see how the little math processor is working up here in his brain

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
and is lighting up the whole brain.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
Well this is fantastic. We can do this in real time.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
We can investigate things. We can tell him to do things.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
You can also see that his visual cortex

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
is activated in the back of the head,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
because that's where he's seeing, he's seeing his own brain.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
And he's also hearing our instructions

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
when we tell him to do things.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
The signal is really deep inside of the brain as well,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
and it's shining through,

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
because all of the data is inside this volume.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
And in just a second here you will see --

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
okay, here. Motts, now move your left foot.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
So he's going like this.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
For 20 seconds he's going like that,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
and all of a sudden it lights up up here.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
So we've got motor cortex activation up there.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
So this is really, really nice,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
and I think this is a great tool.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
And connecting also with the previous talk here,

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
this is something that we could use as a tool

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
to really understand

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
how the neurons are working, how the brain is working,

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
and we can do this with very, very high visual quality

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
and very fast resolution.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
Now we're also having a bit of fun at the center.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
So this is a CAT scan -- Computer Aided Tomography.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
So this is a lion from the local zoo

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
outside of Norrkoping in Kolmarden, Elsa.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
So she came to the center,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
and they sedated her

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
and then put her straight into the scanner.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:16.958
And then, of course, I get the whole data set from the lion.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
And I can do very nice images like this.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
I can peel off the layer of the lion.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
I can look inside of it.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
And we've been experimenting with this.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
And I think this is a great application

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
for the future of this technology,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
because there's very little known about the animal anatomy.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
What's known out there for veterinarians is kind of basic information.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
We can scan all sorts of things,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
all sorts of animals.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
The only problem is to fit it into the machine.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
So here's a bear.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
It was kind of hard to get it in.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
And the bear is a cuddly, friendly animal.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
And here it is. Here is the nose of the bear.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
And you might want to cuddle this one,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
until you change the functions and look at this.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
So be aware of the bear.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
So with that,

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
I'd like to thank all the people

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
who have helped me to generate these images.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
It's a huge effort that goes into doing this,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
gathering the data and developing the algorithms,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
writing all the software.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
So, some very talented people.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
My motto is always, I only hire people that are smarter than I am

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
and most of these are smarter than I am.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
So thank you very much.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:26.958
(Applause)

title: Silicon-based comedy
transcript: Some of the greatest innovations and developments in the world often happen at the intersection of two fields. So tonight I'd like to tell you about the intersection that I'm most excited about at this very moment, which is entertainment and robotics. So if we're trying to make robots that can be more expressive and that can connect better with us in society, maybe we should look to some of the human professionals of artificial emotion and personality that occur in the dramatic arts. I'm also interested in creating new technologies for the arts and to attract people to science and technology. Some people in the last decade or two have started creating artwork with technology. With my new venture, Marilyn Monrobot, I would like to use art to create tech.(Laughter)So we're based in New York City. And if you're a performer that wants to collaborate with an adorable robot, or if you have a robot that needs entertainment representation, please contact me, the Bot-Agent. The bot, our rising celebrity, also has his own Twitter account: @robotinthewild. I'd like to introduce you to one of our first robots, Data. He's named after the Star Trek character. I think he's going to be super popular. We've got the robot — in his head is a database of a lot of jokes. Now each of these jokes is labeled with certain attributes. So it knows something about the subject; it knows about the length. It knows how much it's moving. And so it's going to try to watch your response. I actually have no idea what my robot is going to do today.(Laughter)It can also learn from you about the quality of its jokes and cater things, sort of like Netflix-style, over longer-term to different communities or audiences, children versus adults, different cultures. You can learn something from the robot about the community that you're in. And also I can use each one of you as the acting coach to our future robot companions. Some of you in this middle section — you have red/green paddles. If you like what's going on, show the green. If you don't like the subject or the performance, you can hold the red. Now don't be shy. It's just a robot. It doesn't have feelings ... yet. (Laughter) And the rest of you, you still count, you still matter. There's also a microphone that's listening to the aggregate laughter and applause and booing — I hope not — to help make some of its next decisions. Right, so, let the robot stand-up comedy begin.Data: Hello TEDWomen. It's an honor to be here.(Laughter)(Applause)You guys are looking good out there. Ready for some jokes?Audience: Yeah.Data: Here's the first one. Right, so, a doctor says to his patient, "I have bad news and worse news. The bad news is that you only have 24 hours to live." "That's terrible," said the patient. "How can the news possibly be worse?" "I've been trying to contact you since yesterday."(Laughter)(Applause)The Swiss have an interesting army. Five hundred years without a war. Heather Knight: He's talking about the Swiss. Data: Pretty lucky for them. Ever see that little Swiss Army knife they have to fight with? "Come on buddy, I have the toe clippers right here. You get past me, the guy behind me has a spoon."(Laughter)HK: He's a French robot.Data: A couple of New Jersey hunters are out in the woods. One of them falls to the ground. He does not seem to be breathing. The other guy whips out his cell phone and calls 911. He gasps to the operator, "My friend is dead. What can I do?" The operator says, "Just take it easy. I can help. First, let's make sure he's dead." There is a silence, and the operator hears a shot. The guy's voice comes back on the line, "Okay, now what?"(Laughter)(Applause)Question: Why is television called a medium? Anyone? Because it's neither rare nor well done. But to be completely honest with you, I kind of love television. Any of you like television? Audience: Yes. Data: I find it incredibly educational. Actually, as soon as someone turns it on, I go into the other room and read. (Laughter) That's all for now. Was that okay for my first time?(Applause)You've been a great audience. Thank you.HK: Yay.(Applause)So this is actually the first time we've ever done live audience feedback to a performance. So thank you all for being a part of it. There's a lot more to come. And we hope to learn a lot about robot expression.Thank you very much.(Applause)

If you don't like the subject or the performance,

Data: Here's the first one.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
"That's terrible," said the patient.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:41.958
"How can the news possibly be worse?"

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.958

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
(Laughter)

(Applause)

Heather Knight: He's talking about the Swiss.

Data: Pretty lucky for them.

Ever see that little Swiss Army knife

title: Understanding the rise of China
transcript: The world is changing with really remarkable speed. If you look at the chart at the top here, you'll see that in 2025, these Goldman Sachs projections suggest that the Chinese economy will be almost the same size as the American economy. And if you look at the chart for 2050, it's projected that the Chinese economy will be twice the size of the American economy, and the Indian economy will be almost the same size as the American economy. And we should bear in mind here that these projections were drawn up before the Western financial crisis.A couple of weeks ago, I was looking at the latest projection by BNP Paribas for when China will have a larger economy than the United States. Goldman Sachs projected 2027. The post-crisis projection is 2020. That's just a decade away. China is going to change the world in two fundamental respects. First of all, it's a huge developing country with a population of 1.3 billion people, which has been growing for over 30 years at around 10 percent a year.And within a decade, it will have the largest economy in the world. Never before in the modern era has the largest economy in the world been that of a developing country, rather than a developed country. Secondly, for the first time in the modern era, the dominant country in the world — which I think is what China will become — will be not from the West and from very, very different civilizational roots.Now, I know it's a widespread assumption in the West that as countries modernize, they also westernize. This is an illusion. It's an assumption that modernity is a product simply of competition, markets and technology. It is not. It is also shaped equally by history and culture. China is not like the West, and it will not become like the West. It will remain in very fundamental respects very different. Now the big question here is obviously, how do we make sense of China? How do we try to understand what China is? And the problem we have in the West at the moment, by and large, is that the conventional approach is that we understand it really in Western terms, using Western ideas. We can't. Now I want to offer you three building blocks for trying to understand what China is like, just as a beginning.The first is this: that China is not really a nation-state. Okay, it's called itself a nation-state for the last hundred years, but everyone who knows anything about China knows it's a lot older than this. This was what China looked like with the victory of the Qin Dynasty in 221 B.C. at the end of the warring-state period — the birth of modern China. And you can see it against the boundaries of modern China. Or immediately afterward, the Han Dynasty, still 2,000 years ago. And you can see already it occupies most of what we now know as Eastern China, which is where the vast majority of Chinese lived then and live now.Now what is extraordinary about this is, what gives China its sense of being China, what gives the Chinese the sense of what it is to be Chinese, comes not from the last hundred years, not from the nation-state period, which is what happened in the West, but from the period, if you like, of the civilization-state. I'm thinking here, for example, of customs like ancestral worship, of a very distinctive notion of the state, likewise, a very distinctive notion of the family, social relationships like guanxi, Confucian values and so on. These are all things that come from the period of the civilization-state. In other words, China, unlike the Western states and most countries in the world, is shaped by its sense of civilization, its existence as a civilization-state, rather than as a nation-state. And there's one other thing to add to this, and that is this: Of course we know China's big, huge, demographically and geographically, with a population of 1.3 billion people. What we often aren't really aware of is the fact that China is extremely diverse and very pluralistic, and in many ways very decentralized. You can't run a place on this scale simply from Beijing, even though we think this to be the case. It's never been the case.So this is China, a civilization-state, rather than a nation-state. And what does it mean? Well, I think it has all sorts of profound implications. I'll give you two quick ones. The first is that the most important political value for the Chinese is unity, is the maintenance of Chinese civilization. You know, 2,000 years ago, Europe: breakdown — the fragmentation of the Holy Roman Empire. It divided, and it's remained divided ever since. China, over the same time period, went in exactly the opposite direction, very painfully holding this huge civilization, civilization-state, together.The second is maybe more prosaic, which is Hong Kong. Do you remember the handover of Hong Kong by Britain to China in 1997? You may remember what the Chinese constitutional proposition was. One country, two systems. And I'll lay a wager that barely anyone in the West believed them. "Window dressing. When China gets its hands on Hong Kong, that won't be the case." Thirteen years on, the political and legal system in Hong Kong is as different now as it was in 1997. We were wrong. Why were we wrong? We were wrong because we thought, naturally enough, in nation-state ways. Think of German unification, 1990. What happened? Well, basically the East was swallowed by the West. One nation, one system. That is the nation-state mentality. But you can't run a country like China, a civilization-state, on the basis of one civilization, one system. It doesn't work. So actually the response of China to the question of Hong Kong — as it will be to the question of Taiwan — was a natural response: one civilization, many systems.Let me offer you another building block to try and understand China — maybe not sort of a comfortable one. The Chinese have a very, very different conception of race to most other countries. Do you know, of the 1.3 billion Chinese, over 90 percent of them think they belong to the same race, the Han? Now, this is completely different from the world's [other] most populous countries. India, the United States, Indonesia, Brazil — all of them are multiracial. The Chinese don't feel like that. China is only multiracial really at the margins. So the question is, why? Well the reason, I think, essentially is, again, back to the civilization-state. A history of at least 2,000 years, a history of conquest, occupation, absorption, assimilation and so on, led to the process by which, over time, this notion of the Han emerged — of course, nurtured by a growing and very powerful sense of cultural identity.Now the great advantage of this historical experience has been that, without the Han, China could never have held together. The Han identity has been the cement which has held this country together. The great disadvantage of it is that the Han have a very weak conception of cultural difference. They really believe in their own superiority, and they are disrespectful of those who are not. Hence their attitude, for example, to the Uyghurs and to the Tibetans.Or let me give you my third building block, the Chinese state. Now the relationship between the state and society in China is very different from that in the West. Now we in the West overwhelmingly seem to think — in these days at least — that the authority and legitimacy of the state is a function of democracy. The problem with this proposition is that the Chinese state enjoys more legitimacy and more authority amongst the Chinese than is true with any Western state. And the reason for this is because — well, there are two reasons, I think. And it's obviously got nothing to do with democracy, because in our terms the Chinese certainly don't have a democracy. And the reason for this is, firstly, because the state in China is given a very special — it enjoys a very special significance as the representative, the embodiment and the guardian of Chinese civilization, of the civilization-state. This is as close as China gets to a kind of spiritual role.And the second reason is because, whereas in Europe and North America, the state's power is continuously challenged — I mean in the European tradition, historically against the church, against other sectors of the aristocracy, against merchants and so on — for 1,000 years, the power of the Chinese state has not been challenged. It's had no serious rivals. So you can see that the way in which power has been constructed in China is very different from our experience in Western history. The result, by the way, is that the Chinese have a very different view of the state. Whereas we tend to view it as an intruder, a stranger, certainly an organ whose powers need to be limited or defined and constrained, the Chinese don't see the state like that at all. The Chinese view the state as an intimate — not just as an intimate actually, as a member of the family — not just in fact as a member of the family, but as the head of the family, the patriarch of the family. This is the Chinese view of the state — very, very different to ours. It's embedded in society in a different kind of way to what is the case in the West.And I would suggest to you that actually what we are dealing with here, in the Chinese context, is a new kind of paradigm, which is different from anything we've had to think about in the past. Know that China believes in the market and the state. I mean, Adam Smith, already writing in the late 18th century, said, "The Chinese market is larger and more developed and more sophisticated than anything in Europe." And, apart from the Mao period, that has remained more or less the case ever since. But this is combined with an extremely strong and ubiquitous state. The state is everywhere in China. I mean, it's leading firms — many of them are still publicly owned. Private firms, however large they are, like Lenovo, depend in many ways on state patronage. Targets for the economy and so on are set by the state. And the state, of course, its authority flows into lots of other areas — as we are familiar with — with something like the one-child policy.Moreover, this is a very old state tradition, a very old tradition of statecraft. I mean, if you want an illustration of this, the Great Wall is one. But this is another, this is the Grand Canal, which was constructed in the first instance in the fifth century B.C. and was finally completed in the seventh century A.D. It went for 1,114 miles, linking Beijing with Hangzhou and Shanghai. So there's a long history of extraordinary state infrastructural projects in China, which I suppose helps us to explain what we see today, which is something like the Three Gorges Dam and many other expressions of state competence within China. So there we have three building blocks for trying to understand the difference that is China — the civilization-state, the notion of race and the nature of the state and its relationship to society.And yet we still insist, by and large, in thinking that we can understand China by simply drawing on Western experience, looking at it through Western eyes, using Western concepts. If you want to know why we unerringly seem to get China wrong — our predictions about what's going to happen to China are incorrect — this is the reason. Unfortunately, I think, I have to say that I think attitude towards China is that of a kind of little Westerner mentality. It's kind of arrogant. It's arrogant in the sense that we think that we are best, and therefore we have the universal measure. And secondly, it's ignorant. We refuse to really address the issue of difference. You know, there's a very interesting passage in a book by Paul Cohen, the American historian. And Paul Cohen argues that the West thinks of itself as probably the most cosmopolitan of all cultures. But it's not. In many ways, it's the most parochial, because for 200 years, the West has been so dominant in the world that it's not really needed to understand other cultures, other civilizations. Because, at the end of the day, it could, if necessary by force, get its own way. Whereas those cultures — virtually the rest of the world, in fact, which have been in a far weaker position, vis-a-vis the West — have been thereby forced to understand the West, because of the West's presence in those societies. And therefore, they are, as a result, more cosmopolitan in many ways than the West.I mean, take the question of East Asia. East Asia: Japan, Korea, China, etc. — a third of the world's population lives there. Now the largest economic region in the world. And I'll tell you now, that East Asianers, people from East Asia, are far more knowledgeable about the West than the West is about East Asia. Now this point is very germane, I'm afraid, to the present. Because what's happening? Back to that chart at the beginning, the Goldman Sachs chart. What is happening is that, very rapidly in historical terms, the world is being driven and shaped, not by the old developed countries, but by the developing world. We've seen this in terms of the G20 usurping very rapidly the position of the G7, or the G8. And there are two consequences of this. First, the West is rapidly losing its influence in the world. There was a dramatic illustration of this actually a year ago — Copenhagen, climate change conference. Europe was not at the final negotiating table. When did that last happen? I would wager it was probably about 200 years ago. And that is what is going to happen in the future.And the second implication is that the world will inevitably, as a consequence, become increasingly unfamiliar to us, because it'll be shaped by cultures and experiences and histories that we are not really familiar with, or conversant with. And at last, I'm afraid — take Europe; America is slightly different — but Europeans by and large, I have to say, are ignorant, are unaware about the way the world is changing. Some people — I've got an English friend in China, and he said, "The continent is sleepwalking into oblivion." Well, maybe that's true, maybe that's an exaggeration. But there's another problem which goes along with this — that Europe is increasingly out of touch with the world — and that is a sort of loss of a sense of the future. I mean, Europe once, of course, once commanded the future in its confidence. Take the 19th century, for example. But this, alas, is no longer true.If you want to feel the future, if you want to taste the future, try China — there's old Confucius. This is a railway station the likes of which you've never seen before. It doesn't even look like a railway station. This is the new [Wuhan] railway station for the high-speed trains. China already has a bigger network than any other country in the world and will soon have more than all the rest of the world put together. Or take this: now this is an idea, but it's an idea to be tried out shortly in a suburb of Beijing. Here you have a megabus, on the upper deck carries about 2,000 people. It travels on rails down a suburban road, and the cars travel underneath it. And it does speeds of up to about 100 miles an hour. Now this is the way things are going to move, because China has a very specific problem, which is different from Europe and different from the United States: China has huge numbers of people and no space. So this is a solution to a situation where China's going to have many, many, many cities over 20 million people.Okay, so how would I like to finish? Well, what should our attitude be towards this world that we see very rapidly developing before us? I think there will be good things about it and there will be bad things about it. But I want to argue, above all, a big-picture positive for this world. For 200 years, the world was essentially governed by a fragment of the human population. That's what Europe and North America represented. The arrival of countries like China and India — between them 38 percent of the world's population — and others like Indonesia and Brazil and so on, represent the most important single act of democratization in the last 200 years. Civilizations and cultures, which had been ignored, which had no voice, which were not listened to, which were not known about, will have a different sort of representation in this world. As humanists, we must welcome, surely, this transformation, and we will have to learn about these civilizations.This big ship here was the one sailed in by Zheng He in the early 15th century on his great voyages around the South China Sea, the East China Sea and across the Indian Ocean to East Africa. The little boat in front of it was the one in which, 80 years later, Christopher Columbus crossed the Atlantic. (Laughter) Or, look carefully at this silk scroll made by ZhuZhou in 1368. I think they're playing golf. Christ, the Chinese even invented golf.Welcome to the future. Thank you.(Applause)
